He said: Mr. Speaker, it is a privilege to rise to ask the House to adopt this motion, a motion which calls for the government to require the cessation of visits to harbours in the Victoria area of nuclear powered vessels or vessels that may be carrying nuclear weapons until a full public inquiry has been completed including an environmental assessment.
This motion is of importance to the people in our area but it is also important, I believe, to the people of Canada because it represents a very important environmental issue and it represents a very important issue in terms of our national and international policies.
The effect of this motion could equally apply to other harbours in Canada and to other waters. However it is addressed in this way as I represent the Victoria area. I am familiar with the issues there. I wish to speak very specifically to the impact of these visits on the Victoria area and my recommendations to this House for dealing with the consequences of these visits.
I believe I speak for the overwhelming majority of people of the Victoria area. All MPs in the area are in support of this motion and of its intent. Eight of the ten local councils have called upon the federal government to have a moratorium on these visits until there has been a full environmental assessment.
Recently the British Columbia legislature voted 51 to 1 in favour of declaring British Columbia a nuclear weapons free zone. If I may read the motion, it endorses in effect the motion I have before the House. The motion was adopted on April 24, 1992 by a vote of 51 to 1 and therefore included not only members of the government party, the New Democratic Party, but Liberals and Social Credit as well. In fact only one Social Credit member voted against the resolution. It read as follows:
Be it resolved that the Legislative Assembly of British Columbia declare British Columbia a nuclear weapons free zone; and be it further resolved that this Assembly calls on the Government of Canada to conduct a full public environmental review of the dangers involved by the presence of nuclear weaponed and nuclear powered vessels in British Columbia's harbours and waterways.
This all-party support for the resolution coincided with the passage of similar resolutions by the provinces of Ontario and Manitoba, the territories of Yukon and the Northwest Territories, as well as hundreds of municipalities across Canada.
I would acknowledge there are some in our area who have concerns about this resolution. They are particularly supportive of the visits to the Victoria area by U.S., French and British vessels. They are concerned that this kind of resolution or approach will inhibit the visits of foreign vessels to our harbours. They wish to have the visits continue because they believe it is an act of friendliness to our neighbours. As well the commerce that our area enjoys as a result of these visits is something they wish to continue.
Let it be said that for my part-I believe my colleagues and the municipalities in the area agree-we too would like to see the visits continued but only after there has been a proper environmental assessment of the impact

June 1, 1992
Private Members' Business
of the visits and there is an agreement worked out that there will be no nuclear weapons on board the vessels coming into our area as a matter of national and provincial policy.
Last week I met with the chamber of commerce which represents these views. It has done an outstanding job in welcoming sailors, officers and crews of the vessels that have come into Victoria harbour. I frankly believe that an accommodation can be worked out with the chamber on these issues. It certainly joins in its concern for the environmental issue and for the public concerns arising around that issue.
As well, as I will point out later in the debate, there have been significant foreign policy changes in the United States which should lead this government toward taking some new and fresh steps to resolve this issue and these very vital concerns of the people in our area.
I have met with the Naval Officers Association of Vancouver Island. In fact I am a member of the association. It has sent correspondence and conducted a number of discussions with me. Many distinguished naval officers, including retired naval officers, are concerned with this issue and have raised a number of important considerations.
What it boils down to is that there are two issues confronting the Government of Canada on these visits. The first is an environmental issue. The second is an issue of national policy.
Let me deal with the environmental issue first. There can be no dispute whatever from the government that the consequences of an accident in an urban area such as Victoria, or any other urban harbour in Canada, would be absolutely catastrophic. There can be no doubt about that proposition. A serious nuclear accident in a built-up area such as Victoria would be absolutely catastrophic. There is no amount of emergency preparedness that could properly respond to such a crisis. As well more minor accidents can still have a very serious deleterious effect on the environment in our area.
Our area is asking the House to provide for an environmental assessment of visits of particularly nuclear powered vessels coming into our area, primarily those of the U.S. navy but also of the British and French navies, and to look at the consequences even of carrying nuclear weapons into the area.
Let us focus on the nuclear power for a minute. There have been those who have studied this issue carefully and have concluded that not only are the consequences of an accident serious but the potential risks are real. Over the lifetime of nuclear power there have been sufficient numbers of accidents around the world that the risk of an accident either minor or major is significant. There are others who have studied the issue who say that that is not correct.
It is the view in our area-I believe it ought to be supported by members of Parliament in this House-that given the consequences of an accident there should be no gambling on the risks and that those risks should be carefully and thoroughly examined by a public environmental assessment.
This is not a particularly radical view. It is in fact the view of the government agency charged with responsibility for deciding whether or not an environmental assessment is necessary. I draw the attention of the House to a memorandum prepared by the Federal Environmental Assessment Review Office in August 1991. It was approved by the director general of operations, went to the government and was overruled by the government when it adopted an Order in Council waiving the necessity of environmental review.
Let me take this House through this memorandum. It
states the issue:
Whether to support National Defence's proposal to seek an Order
in Council approval for this activity,-
That is, port visits by nuclear powered vessels. It continues:
-rather than assess it in accordance with the EARP Guidelines
Order.
The memorandum points out:
The Deputy Minister of National Defence wrote, in February
1991, describing the sensitivity of this subject and suggesting the
adoption of the above strategy to avoid the possibility of a public
review.
The minister was asked to decide whether the initial assessment should be done by EARP, whether there should be a public review. DND persisted on the issue and FEARO, the Federal Environmental Assessment Review Office, was considering whether or not Environment Canada had a different view.
It was clear that Environment Canada did in fact have a different view. It said:
June 1, 1992

EARP clearly applies to the decision to authorize port visits by these vessels. The visits constitute a physical activity that is confined to a few ports located on the east and west coasts, an activity that lends itself readily to initial assessment.
DND has the authority to approve the visits and would be initiating authority under EARP. However, the government was concerned there would be legal challenges to the order. A request was going forward to the government in respect of Dixon Entrance, so that DND coupled that request with an over-riding request in respect of all visits of nuclear powered vessels to harbours.
FEARO has strongly recommended to external affairs that the results of the analysis done by others to respond to the public request be made available to the standing committee of the House of Commons on the environment. It should be recommended that external affairs conduct an assessment in accordance with cabinet procedures that officials provide advice on the assessment procedure and that DND is fully aware of it.
The recommendation goes on to say:
National Defence's reluctance to conduct an initial assessment under the EARP needs to be questioned. It has come to our attention that the United States conducted an environmental review with extensive public involvement of an acoustic testing facility for nuclear submarines to be located at Behm Canal in Alaska, notwithstanding the obvious defence-related sensitivity of that facility. If such public consultation was possible for the United States in that situation, should it not be possible for Canada to do the same in this case, before National Defence takes its decision?
The memorandum goes on to say:
While FEARO recognizes there is some risk that opponents could seek a court judgment, we believe that the Point Aconi judgment offers some precedent to allow the National Defence Department to mount a successful argument.
The Order in Council approach is not risk-free-
It then concludes:
We reiterate our opinion that EARP applies to the decision to authorize the port visits, and that National Defence is the initiating department.
The memorandum re-states firmly the view and recommends that the minister re-state firmly the view that it would be preferable to follow the process rather than to avoid it.
Private Members' Business
No pressing security argument has been advanced for avoiding a public environmental assessment review of this issue. If any government authority proposed to put on land a nuclear power plant, there would be the most comprehensive review of that decision. It would be done nationally, provincially and locally.
What excuse can be given to the citizens of any community when a nuclear power plant is brought in by sea, for avoiding an assessment of the environmental impact of that decision? There can be none.
If the government proposes to raise security as an argument, let the government propose procedures for the security aspects of the case to be determined in camera. Let there be appointed an independent assessor who will have the confidence of the community, the Department of National Defence, External Affairs, and so forth, who can make an environmental review of the impact of this decision.
Our community calls on the House to request the government to ensure that such a review takes place.
I would like to draw the attention of the House to another document that has come to my attention. As the House will know, the New Zealand government is reviewing its policy. As well the Senate of Australia is reviewing the issues in that part of the world. In the course of the inquiries there, a secret U.S. Navy document has come to light which instructs commanders that they do not necessarily need to contact all the relevant authorities like foreign governments when a nuclear powered vessel has an accident in a foreign port. This would violate the terms of the basic agreement between the United States and foreign governments, and I assume the terms of the agreement between Canada and the United States in respect of these visits.
I want to ask the parliamentary secretary who will be speaking on behalf of the government to move quickly on this and to look into this particular document.
Let me conclude my remarks by addressing the second issue, which is the issue of national policy.
It is my view and I hope the view of this House-it is certainly the view of the B.C. legislature and 68 per cent of the people of British Columbia according to a recent public opinion survey-that Canada should be a nuclear weapons-free zone.

Private Members' Business
The government makes the argument that we are somehow protected by the U.S. nuclear umbrella as part of our collective security arrangements with the United States and through NATO. So I may say do the Liberal opposition. The Liberals as well as the government make the case that these visits should continue and that nuclear weapons should be brought into Canada.
Let me say first that nuclear weapons provide no protection whatever against a nuclear attack. Even if there had been an argument once upon a time before the end of the cold war that the nuclear deterrent was in fact an effective deterrent against a Soviet nuclear attack on North America, that argument can no longer be made.
Clearly Russia, the successor state in this respect and to some extent the Ukraine and perhaps other states in that part of the world, present no strategic nuclear threat to Canada and the United States at this time.
A year ago the right hon. Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs when he was Secretary of State for External Affairs described the then Soviet Union as an ally and a friend of Canada. The case cannot be made that we are threatened today, and it certainly cannot be made that nuclear weapons in Victoria harbour present any deterrent to any potential assault.
In September there was a decisive change in U.S. government policy when President Bush announced the withdrawal of tactical nuclear weapons from their naval forces. Today most of the vessels, if not all of the vessels, coming into Victoria harbour probably do not carry nuclear weapons.
Until now the Government of Canada has accepted the argument that the United States government will neither confirm nor deny whether it has nuclear weapons on board. If it is true that the sense of crisis has seriously diminished, as it has, then I call on the government, in light of the changing conditions since the end of the cold war, to renew its discussions with the United States and conclude a new agreement under which the United States will indicate clearly that there are no nuclear weapons on board any vessels coming into Victoria.
It is time to change our policy, to look afresh at these issues and to give the people of Victoria and the people of Canada the assurance that we have entered into a new day, that the environmental considerations will be paramount and that we will have new policies which reflect the reality of today, that we should be nuclear free not only in Canada, but throughout the world.

speakeroldname: Mr. Patrick Boyer (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Defence):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a pleasure to see you presiding here this morning in the House.
If you have a sense of deja vu with respect to this debate, it is because the hon. member for Victoria has raised this same issue previously. We had a debate following somewhat the same lines at least as far as his comments are concerned on February 18.
He raises two issues in his speech, one relating to safety of nuclear vessels coming into Canadian waters and the other the dimension of the environmental impact. I would like to deal with both of those. I know my colleague from Calgary Southwest is going to be dealing later with the broader collective security approach that we have with our allies. Perhaps the spokesman from the Liberal Party would also be dealing with that.
In fact, the first point that he made had to do with broad Canadian policy in this whole area. Of course Canadian policy, established by a previous government in 1967, has been one of allowing our allies to visit Canadian ports under certain terms and conditions. That policy has continued whichever party was in power. It is the policy of the Government of Canada. In fact it was renewed last October by Order in Council.
I want to speak about that because in the process of renewing this policy the government did undertake environmental impact studies. My interpretation of them, which may not surprise the House, is somewhat at variance with the interpretation of the member for the New Democratic Party.
Before getting to any of that, I would like to make very clear that when the member mentioned a document that he purports to be a secret U.S. naval document with respect to the non-reporting of accidents of nuclear powered vessels, I do take that seriously. I would ask the member for Victoria to table the document to which he referred. I would also indicate to him that upon it being tabled and seeing it I will investigate the matter and see what is being done in that area because this is a serious issue.
June 1, 1992

Certainly the government does not take that lightly, nor indeed does the government take lightly the question of the safety of nuclear propelled vessels or the environmental impact that they might have. That is why a study was conducted initially by the Department of National Defence prior to an extension of the government policy allowing allied nuclear powered vessels to visit Canadian ports.
After that was completed last year and it was determined by the government that the environmental consequences of these visits are insignificant, and second, that these visits pose no significant risk and hence can be safely accommodated, a review of this was done by Environment Canada at the invitation of DND and the Department of External Affairs.
That process has been referred to on several occasions by the member for Victoria. The results, I want to make it clear, are public. The memorandum he refers to in the House is a public document. There is no effort to hide information; indeed, it is the government's approach to be very open about this because the issues are significant.
The ability of the Canadian government to assess the environmental and safety impact of these vessels is based on a number of factors. First of all, our country has within it experts who are extremely knowledgeable in the philosophy, the principles and the practice of nuclear reactor safety. Canada has been in this field since its inception in the 1940s. Second, Canadian expertise with water reactor design, as well as safety analysis and accident characteristics gives us the ability to make assessments in this area and that expertise was brought to bear on the situation.
In the review there was a comparison of the risks posed by commercial power reactors and marine nuclear propulsion reactors. We looked at the historic record of what has happened over the past 40 years in operating these types of vessels. We made an assessment of the alleged accidents. A lot is said in the popular press and even by some members of Parliament, as we heard about 10 minutes ago, on the nature of these accidents. Sometimes as much heat as light is shed on the issue in the way that those are described.
Private Members' Business
The government also looked at the results of environmental monitoring that have been published in this field. There is a fairly extensive body of knowledge on that. There has been specific environmental monitoring of foreign vessel visits to Canadian ports. We also relied on the assurances given to us by our allies. That was part of the over-all process and it is again in that connection that I refer to the member and hope that he will table that document and I will be sure that everything is as we expect it to be. If it is not, then appropriate action would certainly be taken. Also, we have within the Department of National Defence a lot of people who are very knowledgeable about the nuclear propelled submarines because of the now defunct nuclear submarine acquisition program. A lot of skill and knowledge was built up there.
For all those reasons, the government concluded and subsequently validated by a review by Environment Canada that the policy of the Government of Canada begun in 1967 should be continued.
For practical reasons it is only the United States and the United Kingdom nuclear propelled vessels that visit Canadian designated ports. On the west coast these visits are accommodated at both Esquimalt and Nanoose.
I want to emphasize that nuclear propelled vessels of our allies are only permitted to visit these ports if they satisfy the strictest of nuclear safety criteria. Specifically, only nuclear propelled vessels which satisfy conditions established by the Government of Canada and by the Department of National Defence of Canada are permitted to visit our ports.
The record is public. The monitoring that is done by Canadian teams to detect any release of radioactivity is ongoing. This is the time, in the moments that remain for me, to try and place on record some of the facts that would help to shed light and indeed reassurance on this issue.
Since this policy of allowing foreign vessels of this type to visit our ports the safety record has indeed been excellent. In almost 40 years of visits by allied nuclear propelled vessels to over 150 different ports around the world, there has not been a single reactor accident nor have there been any other types of accidents with these

June 1, 1992
Private Members' Business
vessels which have had a detrimental effect on the environment.
Our Department of National Defence maintains well-trained nuclear emergency response teams at both CFB Comox and CFB Esquimalt to respond in the unlikely event that there ever would be an accident.
I should put on record as well that those teams are not just established for that narrow purpose. They also respond to any nuclear contamination that could occur from the multitude of nuclear material that is used daily in construction, educational, medical, or research activities.
Those teams have been used to assist the civilian or non-military activities at the request of regional authorities. There is a very well-trained nuclear emergency response team detachment at Nanoose. The department works with the local officials to co-ordinate those responses. We are continually evaluating the capacities and effectiveness of those teams.
The final point I would make, and the member has said this, is it is like having a nuclear reactor established in the community waiting for it to explode or something. There is a bit of intentional fear mongering going on there that creates public alarm.
Nuclear propelled vessels and their propulsion plants are designed to prevent a serious accident even in severe conditions at sea. They are built to withstand the rigours of combat and therefore to sustain being damaged.
The risk of loss of life associated by living in proximity to a commercial nuclear power plant for 50 years is comparable to smoking about one and a half cigarettes and the cancer or heart disease that can cause, or living for about two days in a large city and the lung cancer that can be caused by air pollution. There are comparative figures and data. There are a lot of statistics out on this but anyone can see that the relative risks have been assessed and the systems designed to prevent accidents from happening.
The final point I would make in concluding is that since last November 27 when the American President ordered the standing down of all of the U.S. tactical nuclear weapons and removing them from surface ships and submarines, I am advised that the U.S. navy advanced on that as well. While it continues to be, as the member said, the policy of that government neither to confirm nor deny whether its vessels are carrying nuclear
weapons, clearly the announced policy since last September is to step down and remove those nuclear weapons.
There is not the cause for concern because the government has itself a strong concern with the safety of Canadians and the environment.

Mr. Speaker, I want to thank both hon. members for a very good debate on this issue. The debate has given both sides of the issue, essentially the security side and the environmental side which I think has been done so well by my colleague, the hon. parliamentary secretary.
This question really is of a national proportion. May I say at the outset that I have not known the hon. member for Victoria for long but I do know the city of Victoria quite well. With the possible exception of St. John's, Newfoundland, it is probably one of the finer cities in Canada. I can appreciate where he is coming from in that perspective.
And Calgary.

There is Calgary and a few other cities of course.
I would like to put the issue in the proportion of the aspect of security and the totality of that aspect. I want to draw on your experience, Mr. Speaker, of the past, of the history of our country and where we have come from in the last few years.
One of the premises of my presentation this morning is the timing of the hon. member's motion. Now that peace and security are looking a little better than they did a few years ago, then perhaps this might be a good time to have a look at the proposal he puts in front of the House.
I would have to go back and say that the first goal of any country, of any municipality, or of any province is to look after its people. This would drum up a security policy that would take into consideration the hon. member's motion.
We have to put it in the perspective of where we have come from in the last 40 to 45 years. It is no revelation and it is no surprise to anybody here to say that in the last 40 to 45 years we have lived in a period of instability, challenge and a great threat to our security. How that is manifested I suppose is by the billions of dollars that Canada has spent, and other countries have spent against the challenge, the threat and the instability that faced us. It is a fair investment, I would say. It could have been plus 10 per cent, it could have been minus 10 per cent, we will never know.
June 1, 1992

The fact is that we took out an insurance policy on the country, an insurance policy on the continent, an insurance policy to make sure that I and my colleagues could be here speaking in this excellent model of democracy.
Is it time to change our feelings about instability, peace and security? Well, the conventional wisdom is that the end of the cold war has brought us to a point in time where we should consider these things.
Not long ago, I watched a television biography of a great hero of mine and I am sure of many in the House, the Hon. Winston Churchill. A lot of us recall his speech where he talked about the neck of the British Empire being wrung. It was delivered here, I am sure with much more eloquence and elan than I am delivering today. But it is appropriate to remember what he said. One of his expressions was "some chicken, some neck". Well, for those who would look at the end of the cold war as the end of our concerns with instability, challenge and security, I say to them: "Some peace, some security".
It is very difficult to pick up a newspaper today without reading about the difficulties taking place in the world. It is more difficult to read articles on the number of nuclear weapons that still exist.
As the hon. member said, this is not a question of fear mongering, but my hon. colleague the parliamentary secretary used some facts and figures. I will not quote, but there are roughly 25,000 nuclear weapons in the arsenals of both sides.
Again, I am not going to take the hon. member for Victoria out of context, but his thought was nuclear weapons are not needed to protect against nuclear weapons.
Well, if I am fighting an enemy that is 10 feet tall and packing two six-guns on his side and is driving one of these big-wheeled vehicles, I do not think I am going to take him on without the aid of a few friends. In those days it was called deterrence; today it is called hedging.
I will tell you why it is important to hedge. It takes a generation and a half to build up the kind of technology and security that we have in Canada. We cannot take on
Private Members' Business
the world. In fact, we are the second largest country in the world and it has been shown that we cannot defend ourselves alone because of the number of people we have for the size of our country.
Therefore, we rely on a thing called collective alliance. While sometimes it may be difficult to understand this from some of the speeches that have been made in this House, our best neighbour is the United States. There are times when business is business and friendship is friendship. However when we really come down to the final points here, the point is if you belong to a collective alliance, if you belong to a collective defence club and you believe that there is still reason to have concern about peace, instability and danger and if you look at a weekend itinerary of what is happening in the world, then you would have to ask yourself the question, as laudable as the motion may seem superficially and, indeed, in some depth.
In the totality of what we as parliamentarians are expected to do and make decisions on, would it be wise at this time to make a decision that on the surface would seem to be reasonable on environmental assessment? Quite frankly, I do not think it is that unreasonable. It is a judgment call. I have no intention of degrading the motion of the hon. member or saying that it is absolutely out of the question.
What I am saying from where I stand, from the way I have been brought up and from the policies I revere is that perhaps the timing is wrong. The principle is fine but at this particular time in the history of our country I am not so sure it would be a wise move to support this judgment.
If I am allowed another minute or so, I want to go back and look at those past 45 years and what we stood for in Canada. Looking at our contribution to NATO, our contribution to peacekeeping, and our contribution to having the world the way it is today, we can be very proud of our achievements in our country.
While the hon. member's motion may be a move in a direction that the world may be heading somewhat

June 1, 1992
Private Members' Business
downstream-I am looking at the Rio conference and that kind of thing-I think perhaps the timing is a little early. At this particular point in time I suppose the view would be that the organization is there, we support it, you cannot have both sides, and I suppose I would have to say we would entertain the idea at some other time.
You sound like Mackenzie King.
No. I wish I could be perhaps more definite than the gentleman to whom you refer. I would say a good motion but the timing is somewhat perhaps to be achieved downstream.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased to rise today and speak on the motion by the hon. member for Victoria concerning nuclear powered and nuclear capable vessels off the west coast in particular.
While there has been a lot of public discussion on this subject, unfortunately not all of it has been truly well informed. In fact, many well-meaning Canadians are quite confused about the whole issue of these port visits. I do welcome the opportunity to clarify some of the facts.
Specifically, the motion calls for the cessation of visits to harbours in Victoria of nuclear powered vessels, or vessels that may be carrying nuclear weapons until a full public inquiry is done, also including an environmental assessment.
To understand why the government allows these specific port visits-I have to say under the very strictest of criteria, very strictest of guidelines-it is important to appreciate Canada's defence policy.
A lot of the public debate on the visits of what we call NPVs, nuclear propelled vessels, and the NCVs, nuclear capable vessels, ignores the fact that Canada welcomes these visits as a meaningful contribution to collective security. Indeed, much of Canada's history demonstrates the benefits of Canada's commitment to collective security.
I really believe the hon. member for Victoria would agree in the international arena the Canadian forces and its forerunners, the Canadian Army, the Royal Canadian Navy, and the Royal Canadian Air Force, acting in concert with our allies have played a notable, indeed a
very honourable role, both in the establishment and the maintenance of peace in many widely separated areas of the world. This tradition continues today.
In addition to our continuing commitment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, we currently have personnel in the Red Sea enforcing United Nations sanctions against Iraq. We have 1,100 personnel in the Balkans with the European Communities monitoring mission and the United Nations protection force. We have personnel throughout the rest of the world in such places as Angola, Cambodia, El Salvador, the Golan Heights, Kuwait, the Sinai and the western Sahara.
What I am talking about is best described in the April 1992 document Defence Policy 1992. On page 4 of this newly released document is a statement I would like to read:
As a responsible member of the world community, Canada seeks the maintenance of a peaceful international order in which to pursue its own interests. Canadians do not and cannot look with equanimity on violent conflict anywhere in the world. It would not only be reprehensible in itself, but also corrosive to international order and to international stability.
More important, the document does make it clear that Canada maintains its commitment to defence and collective security, arms control and disarmament and the peaceful resolution of all disputes. Canada is a great country with a very small, a very modest armed force.
Again I refer to the Defence Policy 1992. In fulfilling our commitments, in conjunction with like-minded nations, we contribute to a safer and a more secure international environment. We are living in changing times. In only a short period of time we have all witnessed remarkable changes right around the world.
The cold war is over. Germany has been reunified. The former states of the Soviet Union have taken their place in the international community. Arms control regimes are in place to help contribute to a more secure world. Along with the changes there are challenges, and in particular the prospect of international instability is the subject of concern for all members of the international community.
Who of us would have thought that with the end of superpower confrontation Canadian forces personnel would be serving in and around the Persian Gulf? Canada's contribution in that region is an example of the benefits that we realized from collective security efforts.

Furthermore, Canada's success in the gulf was not derived only from the fact that we fielded extremely well trained and very good professional personnel but because we have much experience in operating in concert with our friends and with our allies.
The hon. member for Bonavista-Trinity-Conception has just made statements with regard to friends and collective alliance. This is the only way that we in Canada can have collective security efforts. Successive Canadian governments have recognized for years and years and decades there is absolutely no alternative to collective security.
We are blessed with one of the longest coastlines in the world. We are the second largest territory in the world. From a military perspective this is a major challenge. Added to the physical realities of our country is the fact that with our very modest small population and military resources Canada cannot defend unaided our national territory.
At the same time it should be remembered that there is no free ride. If Canada is going to derive benefits of alliance membership for our own security then Canada must and should be prepared to contribute in return. It is not surprising then that Canada works toward international peace and security in conjunction with those nations with which we share a very similar political principle, similar economic structures and similar social values.
Exchanges with our American friends are quite common, exchanges with their navy, their air force and their army personnel. They make regular visits to Canada. Other allies also visit Canada often using our spacious training facilities.
In this regard we have the British, the Dutch and the Germans. These flyers train out of Goose Bay, Labrador. German soldiers train at the Canadian Forces Base in Shilo, Manitoba. British personnel train at the Canadian Forces Base in Suffield and Wainright, Alberta.
This discussion would not be complete without highlighting Cold Lake, Alberta which indeed has its superb training facilities. The pilots of the CF-18s that played a major place in the Persian conflict some months ago trained in Cold Lake, Alberta.
Government Orders
It is an important part of our alliance in working together with our colleagues. It is not surprising that we do have visits of the NPVs and the NCVs, because we are all working together for peace and security in the country.
While I am pleased to participate today-and I know that security and environment are major factors-we all have to realize that Canada's major role in security policy and our commitment to defence and collective security are the only ways to go.
We are proud of what we have done. The world is not benign. We are moving toward better peace and security. Hopefully we can see that in the not too distant future.

-and surrounding areas of Alberta and the Northwest 'Iferritories remained contentious.

Obviously, I am in favour of protecting the environment; we are all in favour of virtue, but those figures are quite striking when you think that women's groups, ask rather frequently the federal government for funding and their requests are rejected, not to mention that when we ask for a daycare program we are told to wait until next year, only to then find out that there is no longer going to be a daycare program.

The development work done for the park in 1988-89 is defined as follows: the CPS set up an office in North Vancouver which is primarily responsible for the implementation of the agreement. A new office was set up in the Queen Charlotte Islands; its mandate is to manage the Reserve for South Moresby National Park.
At various times during the year, officials from the CPS have negotiated with the Ha'idas-as we know, the
Ha'idas are of course mentioned in the bill-in an attempt to reach a mutually satisfactory agreement on the planning, the management and the operation of the reserve for the national park.
The regional economic development program got under way with studies on the conditions necessaiy for the eventual development of a small craft harbour in Sandspit, the establishment of information and visitor centres in the city of Queen Charlotte and in Sandspit, as well as the setting up of a federal-provincial planning and coordinating committee.

On September 23 1988, after five years of negotiations, the federal and Saskatchewan governments signed an agreement respecting the establishment of Grasslands National Park, that is in the south-west area of the province. This agreement replaced two federal-provincial agreements signed in 1981 concerning the creation of that park, as well as the development of oil and gas resources.
The proposed park will have an east and a west part totalling 906 square kilometres. Under the new agreement, an area of 336 square kilometres was designated as a mineral reserve for the Crown, so that oil and gas exploration are now prohibited activities on that land. I believe it is important to know what is going on in other provinces, and not only in Alberta and in British Columbia, as is now the case with Bill C-59.
Once the federal government-I am referring to Grasslands National Park-will have acquired all this land, the provincial authorities will transfer to it the management and the control of that land. This is yet another park that will be under federal jurisdiction. Of course, the provinces are always asked to give up the land, something of which the Bloc Quebecois does not necessarily approve.

Mr. Speaker, first of all, I would like to thank the hon. member for Saint-Hubert for her speech, and I think the Chair appreciated the information she was able to provide.
However, I am rather concerned about the fact that there are so many national parks across Canada but so very few in Quebec. The hon. member for Saint-Hubert mentioned the money spent on the various parks. I think this is one way for the Government of Canada to inject considerable amounts of money into the regions. However, I know there has always been a certain reluctance in Quebec because of territorial considerations.
I get the impression they often simply want excuses for dumping federal money in certain regions. I am sure there are many towns in Quebec that would have liked to get the kind of money that was spent on Gatineau Park and the Saguenay park reserve. I must say that over the years, the National Parks Act has not been beneficial to Quebec.
Considering that one-third of 1 per cent of the territory subject to the National Parks Act is located in Quebec, this legislation has been used to inject a lot of money everywhere else. Today we are being asked to spend about $300 million, the figure someone mentioned to me.
I am aware the hon. member for Saint-Hubert has read a number of reports, and perhaps she has something to say about the value represented by these parks, because in Quebec, when we are discussing Quebec's future and secession, we are all concerned about the way the assets will be divided. We know there are a few locations in Quebec like Forillon Park and the Mingan Archipelago. The hon. member told us that the Lachine canal-I did not know this-also comes under the National Parks Act.

There are a number of places that would have to be counted as part of our assets.
Payments in lieu of taxes are the usual procedure for office buildings, for instance. The federal government makes in lieu payments instead of paying property taxes. I wonder whether we could decide to share the national parks and we could then get at least one-quarter of the value of all national parks. For instance, this is of course very symbolic. By the way, the same is true, more or less, for national parks.
You are no doubt aware that only three of the 25 national parks in Canada are located in the province of Quebec. Such inequity is very nearly outrageous, when you see what little interest the federal government has shown for the province of Quebec, whether for parks or for science and technology projects. The same thing is happening almost in every case.
About parks, I must say that I am in favour of establishing parks, in so far as we can afford it of course. I am especially in favour of establishing parks equitably. I know why parks are necessary. First, our wildlife needs to be protected. We all know that this is important, at least in certain geographical areas of this great land. There are migratory birds and we have to earmark permanently a place for them, so they can go on travelling, surviving and living. That is why we need wildlife reserves such as parks to allow these birds to settle, feed and breed.
There are also animals that need protection. The problem often with wild animals accustomed to living in parks is that they are hardly protected at all when they wander in commercial or industrial areas, in big cities, in rural areas and so on. We absolutely need specific places where animals, our wildlife in particular, can live and survive.

The government wanted to ram this bill through, to go through first, second and third reading within a couple of hours on Friday, the week before last, and we had not even been informed of this bill.
We simply decided to rise in this House to try and understand better what is going on with parks. I do not think there was any deal.
We also wondered what the rush was with this bill, why it had to pass all three readings on the same day. We were seriously wondering. Personally, I wondered for example about the ongoing constitutional debates. We know that, in this particular case, the responsibility for managing the park would be shared by the natives, the provincial and the federal governments. So, we wondered what the big rush was to entrust the federal government with the management of this park without first making sure, for one thing, that Mr. Ovide Mercre-di, the leader of the native people in Canada, was aware of what was brewing in this House.
Mr. Mercredi is trying to gain more power for the native people in Canada. Did he really know what was going on? I asked myself the question and I wondered what all the rush was. Was the idea to play a trick on Mr. Mercredi by passing a bill swiftly to throw a wrench in his bargaining efforts, as he is talking about the Constitution and wants to bring back certain powers? Do we indeed want to play a trick on him?

Tricks like those are being played on us here in the House of Commons. We asked ourselves if the government was doing the same thing with Mr. Ovide Mercredi and was trying to fool him. We told ourselves that there was no rush and asked ourselves if, during last week's break, we could perhaps do a little research to see if the federal government was trying to fool Mr. Ovide Mercredi. It is for these reasons, among others, that we decided to speak in this House.
Who will really manage that park? Who will really manage it? Will it be the federal government alone or the three levels, that is the federal government, the province and the Indians? I do not know. It seems that it will be the federal government alone. We know that, until now, the federal government was not able to manage its own affairs. It has now accumulated a debt of $450 billion-$450 thousand million-and is on its way to have another deficit of $32 billion. It now wants to rapidly establish a park and create commitments for the next 50 or 100 years, without knowing if we will be able to pay for that park. That too is a serious question that we should ask ourselves.
We ask a lot of questions like those. Is the federal government able to manage a park adequately? Should the Indians not manage it themselves? Would it be better if British Columbia or even a private company did it? Those are all serious questions that we must ask ourselves in order that when that park is actually established and we start pouring money into it, we will be able to afford it and manage it efficiently and adequately, at lower costs than we have had until now.
We know that presently the federal government is unable to manage its own affairs. It is demonstrating its inability to manage the nation's finances since the accumulated debt is now reaching $450 billion and the annual deficit is going to reach $32 billion again. This is why we decided to talk. We want 25 per cent of the moneys which come from Quebec to be spent wisely. Quebecers are contributing $25 billion to Ottawa in direct and indirect taxes, and some would like us to believe that Quebec is receiving presents from the federal government. It never did, the government is

simply returning to Quebec the money it took from our pockets in taxes. The same is true for parks.

Mr. Speaker, I listened attentively to the member for Lon-gueuil. It seemed to me that toward the end of his speech he was asking a lot of interesting and constructive questions. He asked questions that we should all be concerned about concerning the Government of Canada and how we manage the parks of Canada, concerning the relationship of the Government of Canada to the parks of Canada versus the provincial relationship to the parks.
I was getting a strong sense from the member that he was speaking as he once did, as a strong federalist, rather than as he has been speaking in the last few months, which is-as most Canadians would know-as a separatist.
I am getting the sense that the separatist position of the Bloc Quebecois is taking a sudden shift. All of a sudden it is showing a great interest in Canada, her national parks, and the relationship between Canada and her national parks. Is there something new here? Is the Bloc shifting its position from that of a separatist party to that of a federalist party once again?

Absolutely not. Mr. Speaker, we are not in the process of changing our opinion. We are more and more attentive. Since we have decided to protect the interests of Quebec in Ottawa, we represent the citizens of Quebec here, we are more and more attentive to what the federal government does. As we know, Quebecers pay approximately $25 billion per year, that is 25,000 million dollars per year in taxes to Ottawa. Ottawa does not make gifts to Quebec. We are watchful because Quebecers pay about 26 per cent of all the taxes that the federal government spends recklessly. We are here precisely to keep an eye on how the taxes paid by Quebecers are spent in Ottawa.
The park that we are talking about will cost money and it will have to be managed by somebody. What I meant to say is that if it is managed by the federal government, and it has been demonstrated that the federal government is incapable of managing properly the taxes paid by Quebecers to Ottawa, within the Canadian Confederation, I say that one must wonder whether the private

Government Orders
sector could better manage that park and ensure that Quebecers do not have to pay as much taxes to Ottawa to support it. I am not against parks. On the contrary, I am in favour of them and I wish that there would be many more in Quebec, since it seems that only three out of thirty-five national parks are in that province. If I rise today it is because we ask ourselves a lot of questions as to why Quebec is so disadvantaged in that regard. We have been establishing parks in Canada for 100 years. Why is it that Quebec was put at such a disadvantage when its territory is so suited to the creation of parks?
We have mountains and beautiful lakes. We have everything that is needed. Why has Quebec been so neglected in the last 100 years as regards parks, when Quebecers have always paid much more than they have received? If Quebec had collected those $25 billion and spent that money according to its priorities, I am convinced that it would have established more parks than the federal has done in the last 100 years. That is why we are interested in parks. It is not because we are less separatists, but we believe that the sovereignty of Quebec will precisely enable us to create parks adequately and in accordance with the priorities of Quebec. No, it is still the federal government that decides for Quebec, according to federal priorities. Unfortunately, the federal priorities are not the same as the priorities of Quebec. In Quebec, we would like to have more parks. That is why we rise today and say so to the population of that province. We rise today because we only represent Quebec. And we are the only ones. Of course, there is not a single Conservative member, nor a Liberal, because they only look after their own small personal interest. They want to become parliamentary secretaries or even ministers. We are not interested in becoming parliamentary secretaries or ministers; in fact, we are not even interested in gaining total power. We are only interested in having the power to protect the interests of Quebec and watch how the taxes paid by Quebecers are spent for as long as it will take before we can fully manage our own affairs, collect all of our taxes, and spend them according to our own priorities.
We will conclude economic and defence arrangements with the rest of Canada. Of course we are open. Ideally,
and I am answering to the hon. member, a strong and united Canada with a sovereign Quebec would be ideal. It would not be necessary for us to rise in this House to protect the interests of Quebec. Our province would collect all of our taxes and would negotiate with the rest of Canada to decide on the parks that should or should not be created. It is for those reasons that I am more and more sovereignist; it is because I think that we were not well served by the Canadian federation. This is a blatant example, because in the last 100 years, the federal government only established three parks in Quebec while it created 32 in the rest of the country. This is proof that Quebec did not get a fair treatment in this country.
It is for all those reasons that Quebecers want to collect their own taxes and manage their money according to their priorities. It is for those reasons that the majority of Quebecers, and francophones in particular, have decided to opt for a sovereign Quebec associated with a united Canada. That English Canada form a united and strong nation is great, but Quebec will spend its money according to its priorities, and both sides will benefit. In fact, I am convinced that both sides will do better. That is why the Bloc Quebecois has chosen this option.

Mr. Speaker, I welcome the opportunity to take part in this debate on Bill C-59 which concerns our national parks.
Very often we cannot speak in debates that concern Quebec, such as the debate on the constitutional proposals or on the referendum. That is why we believe we must take advantage of every opportunity we have to speak on other matters, especially when the government is trying to expedite bills through the House, which is the case for this bill and even more so for Bill C-81, the referendum legislation.
This debate on national parks is a typical example of the speed with which the federal government is able to deal with matters outside Quebec and its reluctance to deal with matters that concern Quebec, and I am thinking more particularly of the Saguenay marine park.
That is not true.

I do not know whether we will sit on the committee on Bill C-59. The minister said that all parties agreed to support the bill, but he never bothered to consult the Bloc Quebecois. As far as the government is concerned, we do not exist. However, the government and hon. members opposite from Quebec are in for a rude awakening after the next election.
Our members did not sit on the committee on Bill C-81 concerning the referendum and Canada's and Quebec's constitutional future. Committees, as in the case of the committee on Bill C-59, are more or less private clubs from which we are excluded.
To get back to Bill C-59, a number of questions come to mind. For instance, if British Columbia were to become a sovereign state, following a democratic referendum called, need I say, by the authorities of British Columbia and not by the federal government with its anti-democratic manoeuvres, how would the assets be divided? Would this park be federal property? Would British Columbia have to pay certain rights to the federal State? These things must be considered, and that is what the Belanger-Campeau commission did when it con-

Government Orders
suited experts who came not just from Quebec but also from the rest of Canada, France and England. These experts told us that Quebec's share of non-financial federal assets would be equivalent to the ratio of the value of the assets located in Quebec territory to the value of all federal non-financial assets located in Canada and abroad, including embassies, consulates and the like.
We must also determine the real value of the national parks, because they have a value, even if it is hard to define in accounting terms, according to the federal government's own data, because they have not been built on. For example, what is Moresby Park worth or Forillon Park in Gaspe? That will have to be discussed when the time comes for Quebec and Canada to negotiate. We also know that federal government property is not subject to municipal property tax, so there must be some form of compensation. It exists in some cases. We know that Quebec receives only 18 per cent of this kind of compensation paid to municipalities.
I also repeat that Quebec has only three of the 35 national parks in Canada and that there is no compensation for national parks because, as we know, they are not built up but in their natural state.
How would one prepare that report I spoke of earlier on non-financial assets? The value of the national parks must be determined. We know in advance with absolute certainty-it is quite obvious-that Quebec contributes much more than it receives in this regard.
The relationship between the Hai'da nation and the government authorities of British Columbia and Canada must also be specified. The governments should use the James Bay agreement between the Government of Quebec and the federal government and the Cree and Inuit nations as an example. Matthew CoonCome, the Cree Grand Chief, said in the State House in Maine: "As a people, we have the assurance of being able to preserve our way of life with respect to hunting, fishing, trapping and our language and culture. Under the agreement, we obtained what we never had before: full authority over education through the Cree school commission, over social and health services, over managing our lands, and a strong voice in approving new developments on our territory; rights that respect the resources of the land;
rights that guarantee police protection and a judicial system adapted to our needs; guarantees that we can participate fully in developing sub-Arctic Quebec."
That is the kind of agreement that Quebec made with the Cree and that Matthew CoonCome, the Cree Grand Chief, talked about. I think it is important to mention it, because we know that British Columbia has the most land claims and that so far there have been almost no negotiations with the native people because these negotiations only began a year and a half ago, although I stand to be corrected on that.
We should also know whether creating that park will solve the land claims, if the inherent right of native self-government that we hear so much about in the present constitutional circus would accommodate such an agreement or whether the Supreme Court would have to decide in three years. In short, would this park still be part of British Columbia? Would it be a federal enclave or an independently governed native territory? Have provisions been made in this bill to tie it to the constitutional debate so that we can see beyond the few hours we have to discuss it?
We must deal with these issues and these questions are all unanswered right now. They might have a major impact in this time of constitutional discussion.
Despite what the member for Skeena said, we are in favour of creating this park.
There seems to be a problem when we are talking and when we want to talk, nobody wants us to do so. Make up your mind. As far as we are concerned we are quite ready to speak at some length and in great detail on the referendum issue, but nobody wants us to do so. Obviously, we will grab every opportunity possible but, as I said before, we will support the creation of this park. However, it is important to know how much it will cost Quebecers. We do not question the judiciousness of creating this park. We only want to tiy to figure out, in this area as in many others, how much is federalism costing Quebecers.
This park has its raison d'etre and does not represent a totally frivolous expense, unlike the statue to honour the Queen of England which will cost taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars. It seems totally unjustified, especially during a recession, to build a statue of Elizabeth II on a horse.

The national park example, in terms of investments, is an excellent one for any province. In Quebec, the question is different because of the issue of who has control over the territory. You do not build a country, you do not develop a society by relying on unemployment insurance payments. You build a society by investing in research and development, by investing in industries, by investing in tourism via, for example-it is a good one-national parks.
We will therefore support this project and I hope that the questions I asked will be answered, especially as far as asset splitting is concerned, so that Quebec and Canada can start negotiating in earnest the splitting of assets and liabilities once Quebecers have answered yes to a sovereignty referendum held in Quebec according to Bill 150 passed by the National Assembly which is the only legitimate authority to decide what the future of Quebec will be.

Mr. Speaker, Canadians of Greek origin hope the visit of our Secretary of State for External Affairs to Greece and Cyprus will contribute greatly to the solution of the Cyprus issue in accordance with resolutions of the United Nations.
The illegal Turkish occupation forces should be removed as soon as possible. This will enable the subsequent departure of UN peacekeeping forces.
While in Greece, we hope the minister takes the opportunity to hear the views of the Greek government on the Yugoslav crisis. Our government must do everything in its power to prevent further destabilization of the region.
Failure of the former Yugoslav Republic of Skopje to assure its ethnic groups their rights and adopt a name which is not linked to Hellenism threatens to increase the chaos in this turbulent region.
Canada should insist that prior to any recognition Skopje should drop the Greek name Macedonia and respect the culture and traditions of its various ethnic groups, as well as those of its neighbours.

Mr. Speaker, the world is moving to free trade. As tariffs to international trade come down it is necessary to address barriers to efficiency and development at home.
For years negotiations at GATT have been eliminating trade barriers and reducing tariffs between countries. Free trade between Canada and the U.S. came into effect on January 1, 1989.
In Europe, the European common countries have joined together to foster free trade. Australia and New Zealand have a free trade agreement.
Today, as trade barriers disappear around the world, there remains between provinces hundreds of impediments preventing the free movement of goods and
services.
I urge the premiers of the provinces to convene a meeting to address this problem. The restrictions to free movement of goods and services between provinces is hindering economic growth in Canada. We need action now.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in a bid to add perception to reality no less than four Conservative cabinet ministers, including their sidekick from Hamilton-Wentworth, met behind closed doors with Hamilton Mayor Bob Morrow and Hamilton-Wentworth Regional Chairman Reg Whynott last week to discuss local issues.
Incidentally no such meeting has ever taken place since the Tories were elected in the early 1980s.
The Secretary of State for External Affairs, the Minister of State for Small Businesses and Tourism, the Minister for Science and the junior transport minister met with the two Hamilton area officials and pleaded their ignorance on such things as the Hamilton airport, the Hamilton Harbour Commission, and the beleaguered Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and Safety.
Could the ministers have been apologizing? Or did this Tory tea party have anything to do with the timing of an election possibly?
Despite appearances, the foursome could not make up for almost a decade of truancy. A miffed Hamilton Mayor Bob Morrow summed up the feelings Hamiltonians have for the Conservative government's relationship with the city when he said: "It is unfortunate that after eight years in power this is the first meeting we had".
* He *

Mr. Speaker, last September the federal government made 28 proposals for constitutional change. Since then there has been much public polling of what Canadians want to see in a renewed Canada.
June 1, 1992

Of all of this data I have seen none is more supportive than in the case of restoring the right to own property to Canadians. Almost 90 per cent of those polled want property rights entrenched in the Constitution. They want this right, first enshrined in 1215 in the Magna Carta and adopted by the United Nations in 1948, given back to Canadians as a fundamental reform.
As it now stands the west will likely get an elected Senate. Quebec will likely get distinct society status. The aboriginal people will likely get self-government.
Middle-class Canada wants something as well: the right to own property and to be fairly compensated when it is taken away, and the right to challenge politicians and bureaucrats when they pass laws affecting what people own.
I urge the federal government to hang tough in this issue and not to give into the bleatings from the left-wingers who do not think Canadians should be trusted to own property.

Mr. Speaker, Canada's grain industry is in a crisis once again. From prairie elevator to Thunder Bay to Port Cartier, Sept lies and Baie Comeau our elevators are full.
At the same time when as many as 25 ships could be loading Canadian grain in Thunder Bay, this week only three will depart that seaway port. The problem is money.
While Canada has appropriately extended financial credit to Russia and other eastern European countries so they can buy our grain there is no money to pay to ship that very same grain.
In the past this government has quickly acted when labour-management disputes slowed or stopped grain movements. In the government's words they acted in the national interest.
On behalf of farmers, railroaders, grain handlers, weighers and inspectors, seafarers and the hungry people of eastern Europe, I call on the Government of
Canada to act now to find some way to get our grain moving again. It is in the national interest.

Mr. Speaker, June is Seniors Month in Canada, a month to commemorate the great things seniors have done for Canada as well as recognize the contributions seniors continue to make.
Government has an important role to play. The one thing seniors want more than anything else is independence. It is only through co-operation and support that true independence will be achieved. Seniors have the right to choose their own futures and they want government to support that right.
The Liberal Party is committed to seniors and their independence. We appreciate the talent and the experience of seniors and thank them for giving so much to this country.

Mr. Speaker, last Friday, at a press conference help in Rouyn-No-randa, Noranda Minerals Inc. announced, through the CEO for the Home Smelter, that the company has reached, three years before the deadline, its objective of reducing by 70 per cent its SO2 emissions and mineral dust compared to 1980.
At the same time, the CEO announced a financial commitment of $5 million for updating the equipment, in order to reduce SO2 emissions by 90 per cent by the year 2000.
Since that means citizens from Rouyn-Noranda will be breathing 90 per cent fresher air in comparison with 1980, needless to say how such good news were welcome by the people. This is the result of the efforts of all those who campaigned for better air quality in our region.
As I have often said, we have to expose industries which are polluting, but we also have to encourage and congratulate those which take positive action.
So congratulations to the Home Smelter for its environmental achievements.

June 1, 1992

Mr. Speaker, as our constitutional negotiators take a much needed break, we should offer our support and congratulations for their achievements to date.
I would also encourage them to keep working to find acceptable compromises that will keep Canada united.
Despite the fact that we are encouraged by the progress that is being made, it is important to remind all of the negotiators that the first level of government, the family, is not directly represented at these talks.
I urge all participants, federal, provincial and aboriginal, to recognize the importance of families in all our societies and communities. Families formed by men and women freely making commitments to each other, to their role in bringing children into the world and to successfully raising and nurturing children to adulthood, need to be fully recognized in our Constitution.
I urge the Prime Minister, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs, the premiers and aboriginal leaders to ensure that the importance and the role of families are fully recognized.

Mr. Speaker, throughout the last number of months the government has been encouraging Canadians to buy Canadian, to support Canadian entrepreneurs, manufacturers and retailers. The government is also spending money on ads encouraging people not to shop in the United States but to avoid cross-border shopping, to buy Canadian.
Yet all Canadians were shocked over the weekend to find out that in an effort to celebrate Canada's 125th birthday all sorts of paraphernalia-caps, tote bags and pencils-were purchased not in Canada but in the United States and in China.
On one hand the government says one thing and on the other hand purchases caps from China to help celebrate Canada's 125th birthday. We figure this is unacceptable. The government should do what it encourages other Canadians to do from time to time.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Sunday, May 31, was designated World No Tobacco Day by the World Health Organization.
The slogan for the day was: "Tobacco-Free Work Places: Safer and Healthier". Canada has already made giant strides toward achieving smoke-free work places for all employers and employees.
Leadership was provided in 1987 by federal government's provision for smoke-free work places under federal jurisdiction through the public service smoking policy. Many provincial and local governments and corporations have also taken similar action. By late 1991 the Canada Health Monitor Survey was able to report that only 37.6 per cent of Canadians over the age 15 had been exposed to tobacco.
Smoke in the workplace area is unacceptable and our goal is to see that all working Canadians are protected from this workplace hazard in striving for a tobacco free generation.

Mr. Speaker, in 1990 the Task Force on Federally Sentenced Women recommended the creation of a healing lodge which would serve as an incarceration option for federally sentenced women.
Last week the Solicitor General announced that, pursuant to the recommendations of the healing lodge planning committee, the healing lodge would be built near Maple Creek, Saskatchewan, in close proximity to the Nekaneet Band and the historic Cypress Hills. Central to the choice was the long history of peaceful interaction between the native and non-native community in the Maple Creek district, a relationship characterized by mutual respect and cordiality.
The building of the $7 million facility will create some 60 construction jobs and there will be 26 full-time employees and staff. Most important of all, the selection of the Maple Creek-Nekaneet site for the healing lodge is part of this government's ongoing commitment to respect the task force recommendations and thereby
June 1, 1992

better meet the objectives of the Canadian Corrections Service.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
The Prime Minister and his colleagues have been travelling the country in the last month talking about the need for Canada to be competitive and for Canadians to be trained and retrained. His colleague, the Minister of State for Small Businesses, came into the Hamilton area last week and said there were 300,000 jobs going begging for lack of proper training. However, if Canadians follow the government's advice and go down to their local Canada Employment Centre to apply for training, they are told there is no more money for training this year.
How can the minister square his claims that he is moving to make Canada more competitive with the reality that 1.5 million Canadians do not have access to training funds?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, last year some 630,000 Canadians benefited from training programs funded under federal programs. This year, with the changes we have made to the Unemployment Insurance Act, more will benefit. I hate to refer again to the strong opposition of her party to that modification. Today she stands in the House, and the Liberal Party, to complain about there is not being enough money for this developmental use of the UI program which they strongly opposed.
To me, it is inconsistent. Had they not delayed the implementation of Bill C-21 for 18 months, a lot more Canadians would have benefited from that money sooner. Right now, this year, the need of Canadians for training is recognized. Some $3.4 billion will be spent to train Canadians and that is more than last year.
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, Canadians fully remember that one of the first acts of this government was to cut $700 million from training funds that were there under Liberal governments, so we do not need lessons from anybody about putting Canadians back to work.

It is the same old refrain we have heard from this government over and over again. What we want is an answer. The Prime Minister has promised us time and time again that Canada would have the best training and retraining programs in the world. How can they be the best when there is no more money to pay for them?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, if I were to qualify the hon. member's statement I would be unparliamentary. I must inform the hon. member it is absolutely false to claim there are no more funds under the Unemployment Insurance Act or under programs financed from the Consolidated Revenue Fund to train Canadians. There are funds, but they must be managed throughout the year. This year, more Canadians will benefit in absolute numbers from federal training programs than last year.

Mr. Speaker, the number of jobs in the retail trade have gone down for 21 straight months. Jobs in the food and beverage industry have fallen for 25 straight months. Jobs in construction have gone down for 27 straight months. Manufacturing jobs have fallen 28 months straight. The fact is that 1.5 million Canadians are out of work, and as we speak those Canadians do not have access to UI training funds.
My question is for the Prime Minister. What are these
1.5	million Canadians who desperately want to work supposed to do with no training funds?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, again I do not know what the hon. member is trying to do by saying in this House to Canadians that there are no training funds out there.

June 1, 1992
Oral Questions
Throughout Canada this year $3.4 million will be spent. That is $300 million more than last year. How can she stand in this House and tell Canadians there is no training money?
If the Liberal Party is so concerned about training, why does it not start its campaign at the provincial level? Seventy-six per cent of all training funds in this country are spent by this level of government. Training and education are provincial matters which provinces should take seriously.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
I would like to ask the minister to confront the harsh reality. The minister has said there are 300,000 jobs that cannot be filled because Canadians do not have the proper skills. At the same time, thousands of Canadians are being denied access to the training that would enable them to fill those jobs. Obviously the system is not working.
How does the minister intend to fix it?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, how the government intends to fix it is to convince Canadians from coast to coast to coast that the matter of building a training culture in this country is not only a federal matter.
It is something that implicates all levels of government, business, labour, workers and individual Canadians. It is true that the demand for training at this time of high unemployment is resulting in pressures on the funds available. That is why the government increased the number of dollars to be spent to train unemployed Canadians.
If the argument is that we should borrow more or increase the deficit more, or raise taxes to do more than what we are already doing, we think and we suggest that instead, all levels of government that have a stake in the skills of our work force should get together and try to get a system that will work more efficiently.

Mr. Speaker, the point is that we cannot afford to have 1.5 million Canadians unemployed. It is simply not the way to use our human resources.
If the minister would like co-operation, it is going to be extremely difficult to get parties involved. The minister has cut $200 million from the Canadian Jobs Strategy and people will continue to be shut out of the process and training. He is denying them an opportunity for the future. How long must they wait before this government will act?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):

Oh, oh.

Is this acceptable to the minister?

This guy wants to print money.
