Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister. Two weeks ago, at an international conference on the environment in Nairobi, the international community was supposed to approve the convention on biodiversity. By the end of the conference, the United States had managed to rid the text of all substance. However, a few days ago the Americans announced they would not sign the text they had already diluted.
Considering this total refusal by the United States to do anything at all, will Canada immediately initiate a campaign to revert to the original text of the convention, so as to provide better protection for the world's animal and vegetable species?
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, earlier today I indicated that we intend to sign the international convention on biodiversity and that we will also work very hard with our allies to bring about gradual improvements in the text.

Mr. Speaker, the question I asked was whether Canada would push first to go back to the original text, which the Americans had diluted, now that the Americans have refused to sign the text on biodiversity.
The real question is that of the major conventions to be signed in Rio, the one on forestry has been shelved, climate change has been emptied of all content and as we have seen, biodiversity has been critically wounded. The reason is very clear. We are dealing with the selfishness of nations.
Not for a long time has there been an opportunity for Canada to play such a role on the world stage in such a crucial area.
In this, the decisive week, what new initiatives does the government propose to make among the many that have been suggested to infuse needed momentum back into the Rio process?

Mr. Speaker, I have just come from a meeting of some 400 to 500 young Canadians, some of whom will be going to Rio.
I dealt with some specifics as to the objectives of Canada for the Rio conference and the things that we can do, will do, and are in the process of doing to achieve the objectives articulated so eloquently by my hon. friend.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans.
The earth summit is about to begin yet the government lacks the support of some key international players for its fisheries resolution. Last week the minister was in Washington and he hardly managed to get the time of day from the U.S. commerce secretary.

Oral Questions
Now that we know and he knows that the Americans are going to scuttle the resolution at Rio, what contingency plan does the minister have in mind or has he thrown in the towel on this one?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I visited Washington last week on this subject. I met with the secretary of commerce and other officials from her department who are involved with fisheries and also with Congressman Studds who is the chairman of the House of Representatives sub-committee on fisheries and the environment. I had very good meetings down there.
The U.S. has given us considerable support with reference to our resolution which is going forward to the Rio de Janeiro meeting next week. In addition, the Prime Minister met with President Bush and reviewed the fisheries situation with him and with Secretary of State Baker.
The Americans are now fully familiar with the problems we are suffering from overfishing on the nose and tail of the Grand Banks. They are also supportive. The secretary of commerce advised me that they will support our request that there be an international conference under the auspices of the UN on high seas fishing as soon as possible and will support our call for that to occur at Rio de Janeiro next week.

Mr. Speaker, the minister of course is skating a bit on this. The real question is: are the Americans going to support the resolution? I think he himself gave the answer publicly last week and the answer is no.
What action plan does the minister have in mind after Rio, assuming the resolution fails as he allowed it might? What does he plan after Rio to get action on the real issue, the stopping of this pillaging of fish resources off Newfoundland? How will fishermen and plant workers in his riding and in mine be any better off as a result of the summit in Rio next week?

speakeroldname: Hon. John C. Crosbie (Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Minister for the purposes of the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency Act; Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, everyone interested in the fishery will be better off as a result of the summit in Rio next week because this issue will be front and centre at the largest conference ever held on the environment.
Until several months ago, it was not even considered to be an important environmental issue. We now have this issue in its right context.
It is the European Community that claims to be very concerned about the environment and environmental issues, but is preventing our resolution, supported by 40 countries, from having a consensus so far. They are feeling the results of our campaign around the world in this connection. This is shown by the fact that many times in the last several days the Spaniards have announced that they are removing their fleet, even if temporarily, from the nose and tail of the Grand Banks.
We are getting results. I hope that hon. members opposite who have been helpful for the most part would rejoice in the fact that there is some progress being made.
As far as what we are doing in the future, the Prime Minister is going to carry on this cause at the Munich summit of the G-7 powers in July. We will be carrying on our campaign at NAFO in September, and in many other fora during the coming months.

Mr. Brian L. Gardiner (Prince George-Bulkley
Valley): Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Forestry.
Last week, legal counsel on behalf of the federal government wrote to the U.S. department of commerce asking for the exemption of Manitoba, Quebec and Saskatchewan from the softwood countervail dispute with the United States.
Can the minister tell the House the reasons for this move? Can he assure us that this move will not mean that the provinces of B.C., Alberta and Ontario will have to pay a higher price for yet another bad trade deal by this government?

Mr. Speaker, as my friend already knows, the Atlantic provinces have always been excluded from the countervail action. The new findings by the commerce department, which are disputed, also indicate that Quebec and two of the prairie provinces should no longer be included. In the case of Quebec, the duty that is imposed is less than .01 per cent.
June 1, 1992

This is nothing new. My hon. friend knows that we disagree with all aspects of the finding and that it is being fought and appealed to the binational panel, the establishment of which we have called for.

Mr. Speaker, from one bad deal to another. My question is for the Prime Minister.
This government has indicated that the North American free trade agreement would improve the status of Mexican workers and open a market of 85 million to Canadian manufacturers. I was in Mexico last week and these statements are simply not true.
Last week, the Mexican government, labour and business signed a work accord that may or may not increase productivity but did nothing to address the wages of grossly underpaid Mexican workers.
I want to ask the Prime Minister what specific Canadian products will the hundreds of thousands of exploited Maquiladora workers purchase when their present and potential earnings are $4.50 a day?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows that there are discussions besides the NAFTA on labour, on environment, and on other issues.
The hon. member asks what Mexican products come up here and what we are going to do for Mexico.
No. What Canadian products?

At the moment what we have, certainly in the automotive industry, is one-way trade with Mexico. For every car we can bring up here from Mexico, we have to send two and a half to offset this.
There is no doubt at all that we are in the NAFTA agreement because we want to have two-way trade with Mexico, not one-way trade with Mexico.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister and it concerns the Westray mine.
Oral Questions
One thing is crystal clear. If the government had listened to its own bureaucrats there would have been no federal financing, no mine would have been built, and 26 miners would not have lost their lives.
The premier of Nova Scotia has stated that when federal bureaucrats stalled the project he asked his political friend, the Prime Minister, to give the project a green light.
How could the Prime Minister possibly justify proceeding with the project on purely political grounds, overlooking the obvious safety concerns that were raised time and time again by his own bureaucrats?

Mr. Speaker, I will not comment on the specious argument and the misleading statements of my hon. friend. I will say in regard to the fundamental nature of the question, that my role in this was no more nor less than in other cabinet decisions regarding financial assistance for regional development projects.
In this case, federal financial development assistance was provided because the development of the mine with its potential for some 240 direct jobs and 300 or 400 indirect jobs was viewed as a top priority by the Government of Nova Scotia and the people in Central Nova. The mayors, the wardens, trade union leaders, all of the people involved in Central Nova and throughout Pictou County made direct representations asking for financial assistance for what they viewed as an important instrument of regional economic development. After careful consideration, the government agreed to provide assistance as we do in many regional development programs across Canada.
If my hon. friend is in disagreement with that, perhaps he could say so. Those were the grounds on which the government made the decision.

Mr. Speaker, my supplemental is for the Prime Minister. It concerns the same subject matter.
This was not a regular project. Canadians, Nova Scotians, but most particularly, the families of those 26 miners want to know what role politics played in the approval of this project.

Oral Questions
The premier of Nova Scotia has stated that when this project was stalled he contacted the Prime Minister. He said that what the Prime Minister did in response will have to be asked of him.
I ask the Prime Minister: what was his response? What role did he play in overriding the numerous safety concerns of the federal bureaucrats which ultimately resulted in the financing of this ill-fated project?
Hear, hear.

I do not
know why my hon. friends from the Liberal opposition would be applauding a question of this nature.
It is a good question.

No, it is not a good question. The suggestion is that the government would knowingly proceed with something that would jeopardize the wellbeing of people in the interests of regional economic expansion.
My hon. friend asked me what role I played in the decision-making process. I played exactly the same role as I played for example in the decision to proceed with de Havilland in downtown Toronto and when we decided to proceed with development programs in Hibernia in Newfoundland. I was involved in the decision-making process in exactly the same way and pursuant to the same criteria.
The government concluded on the basis of the evidence made available to it that this was in the interests of economic development in Nova Scotia and in Central Nova. Those were the grounds on which we proceeded.

Mr. Speaker, my question likewise is for the Prime Minister.
The government has said over and over again that it was satisfied with the safety conditions in the Westray mine because it was receiving monthly reports from an independent consultant. We now know that that simply was not true, that the person who was supposedly the independent consultant says he did not supply those reports, nor did his company. He merely passed along reports that the Government of Nova Scotia provided.
When will the Prime Minister stop the confusion and say what reports the government did or did not receive, if it received any? Evidently there were some reports in which the government says it put a great deal of faith. What we want is for those reports to be made public today.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if the hon. member had read the newspaper carefully two weeks ago, he would have a quotation from the very mining engineer he has been quoting. Mr. McCandlish said: "I will concur that as late as March I believe we had confirmed independently with the Nova Scotia Department of Labour and the Department of Natural Resources that they, Cur-ragh, were in compliance with the current statutes. That answer was provided and passed on to the bank". He also said that his firm's primary role was to monitor the levels and cost of coal production.
These certificates of compliance were received on a regular basis, but the actual day-to-day monitoring and inspection of the mine was the responsibility of the province of Nova Scotia and those two departments. That is why a judicial inquiry has been established. My hon. friend knows that.

Mr. Speaker, there is a drastic erosion here of the government's position. Now it is telling us it was not concerned with safety in the Westray mine.
Without questioning what information the government had that said the safety conditions were poor in the Westray mine, surely the Prime Minister and the government must have received some information which said that there were no problems with safety in the mine. Surely information of that importance came from somewhere to the federal government before it gave the loan guarantee.
Did it come from Westray? Did it come from Curragh? Did it come from Donald Cameron? Did it come from some other source? Just tell us today where the government based its belief that there were safe conditions in that mine and make those reports public today.

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member can try as hard as he wishes to make this provincial jurisdiction federal jurisdiction.
June 1, 1992
Oh, oh.
Come on.
Give us the detail.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
What the federal government did when it gave the loan guarantee was to make sure that on a regular basis all provincial statutes and regulations that affected the mine would be complied with.
We did that through receiving monthly certificates of compliance. That is what we received. That is what we relied on, but we cannot do independent inspections on our own. That was the job of the jurisdiction that was in charge, the Government of Nova Scotia.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Solicitor General.
Aboriginal women and their supporters were pleased when the decision was made to close the Kingston prison for women and build an aboriginal healing lodge following the suicide death of three aboriginal women from northern Saskatchewan.
These tragic deaths were found to be the direct result of isolation from families and communities. Therefore people are shocked that Maple Creek was chosen as the site for this lodge since only one-half of 1 per cent of the native people in Saskatchewan live within 200 kilometres of the site.
Can the minister please explain how Maple Creek meets the basic criteria of being close to family and the support networks of incarcerated women?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think it is quite evident that aboriginal women would be satisfied with the selection of Maple Creek Nekaneet as the site for the healing lodge. It fulfils all the criteria that they were looking for in terms of being a culturally sensitive environment with running water, plenty of rural land, and a sensitive relationship between the native and non-native communities.
My friend specifically refers to it being equidistant. I remind my hon. friend that this is an aboriginal healing lodge for native women from all of Canada. We do find
Oral Questions
that there are more aboriginal women from the west and in particular from Saskatchewan and Alberta.
I think if my hon. friend checks the geographical distances from both Alberta and Saskatchewan, he will find that the appropriation is appropriate on that basis also.

Mr. Speaker, I do not really care if the politics involved in making this decision came from the aboriginal community or came from partisan politics, or both.
The fact still remains that aboriginal women at Kingston died because of isolation from families and communities. The fundamental problem of isolation will not be solved by putting this healing lodge in a location where there are virtually no aboriginal people, where there is no transportation, where there are no support networks.
Therefore, will the Solicitor General please commit himself to a complete review of the selection process of the aboriginal healing lodge to make sure that another tragic mistake is not being made here?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. In responding to questions regarding Westray, the Prime Minister said and I quote: "My role is no more nor less than other regional development projects".
The Prime Minister will know that the federal government's own Crown corporation, Devco, had written a devastating report pointing out the dramatic safety hazards of the foord seam at the Westray mine.
The Prime Minister will know that senior federal officials had expressed such reluctance, both with respect to the economics of this project and with respect to the safety of this project, that the premier of Nova Scotia felt compelled to call the Prime Minister personally to ask the Prime Minister to intervene to get this project back on the rails.
The question I ask and that Canadians are asking is what did the Prime Minister do that moved forward a project that seemed stuck in neutral prior to Don Cameron's phone call to the Prime Minister's office?

Mr. Speaker, I frequently receive calls from provincial premiers with respect to major regional development projects in their provinces.
My hon. friend represents the province of Newfoundland and Labrador. I can tell him I had many calls from the premier of Newfoundland seeking my support in regard to the Hibernia development project. This is not unusual. It is quite proper and appropriate that it proceed that way.
June 1, 1992

It was conducted in essentially the same way in regard to the regional economic development in Nova Scotia. The decision-making process follows cabinet committee and at the end of the day the government has to decide whether the expenditure of public funds is in the national interest in respect of development and employment-creating programs in Nova Scotia.
In Central Nova, unemployment was high throughout Pictou County. This was seen by everyone as an opportunity to provide long term and good paying jobs. We examined it objectively and we arrived at the conclusion we did.

Mr. Speaker, the issue is not whether or not the Prime Minister of Canada ought to be concerned with regional development. The issue is whether or not the Prime Minister was concerned about safety after he talked to his friend Don Cameron.
What I am asking and what the people of Canada want to know, and I suspect in particular the people of Pictou County want to know, is about the miners who had no union and no other spokesperson and who were counting upon their governments to defend their interest. What action did the Prime Minister take to ensure himself that the concerns raised by Devco in 1988, the concerns raised by senior federal officials about safety in that mine in fact could be answered in a responsible fashion that would justify providing $85 million and opening that mine?
What action did the Prime Minister take to assure himself this was a proper investment and that that mine was safe? Did he take any action to ensure himself in that regard?

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of State has referred to documents that will be tabled in the House. My hon. friend mentioned Devco in his first question. I draw to his attention that, for example, on February 24, 1979, an explosion occurred in the 12th south section of the No. 26 colliery operated by Devco.

The explosion resulted in the death of 12 employees and serious injury to another four employees. A commission of inquiry was struck. The commission concluded that the methane produced from the coal being cut was ignited by sparking from the sheer of steel picks, and that the primary cause of the explosion was the inadequacy of the wall face ventilation that did not prevent a minor ignition from developing into an explosion.
This was a mine owned and operated completely by the Government of Canada. The safety regulations were within federal jurisdiction, as I understand it. In spite of this-and in excess of .$1.3 billion of federal money that had gone into Devco to provide for this-this tragedy occurred.
The coroners of the commission of inquiry concluded that it was methane induced, but I do not think that there was anybody in the House of Commons who rose to suggest that because of the approval of these public funds to develop the mine in Cape Breton, that there was any member of Parliament who was responsible for the safety provisions.
I ask my hon. friend to wait for the response from the commission of inquiry. I think he will be satisfied.

speechtext:
Before commencing Routine Proceedings, I would like to take this opportunity to make a ruling with respect to Bill C-22.
The Chair wishes to announce that it is now prepared to rule on a point of order which was raised on Friday May 22,1992 by the hon. member for Chambly in regard to the admissibility of a report by the Standing Committee on Consumer and Corporate Affairs and Government Operations on Bill C-22, an act to enact the Wage Claim Payment Act, to amend the Bankruptcy Act and to amend other acts in consequence thereof.
The hon. member for Chambly indicated that at a meeting of the committee on May 5, 1992, a series of clauses were deleted from the bill which made its provisions relating to the proposed Wage Claim Payment Act inoperable. He argued that this action went against the principle of the bill as adopted by the House at second reading, and that, consequently, the Standing Committee report is out of order.

There were a number of other submissions made on this point of order, and the Chair is appreciative of the comments offered by the hon. members for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell, Shefford, Saint-Hubert, and the parliamentary secretary to the government House leader.
June 1, 1992

After reviewing the submissions made, the Chair is now prepared to decide on the basic question relating to the amendments adopted by the Standing Committee.

In his presentation, the hon. member for Chambly contended that the House is now dealing with a new and substantially different bill since all provisions relating to the proposed Wage Claim Payment Act have been deleted. Quoting from citation 689(1) of Beauchesne's sixth edition, the hon. member supported his argument with the following passage:
A committee is bound by the decision of the House, given on second reading, in favour of the principle of the bill, and should not, therefore, amend the bill in a manner destructive of this principle.

The logic behind this citation is to prevent the adoption of amendments which would result in a committee straying from the objectives of a bill and all that this may entail. Of course, a committee may not expand on the scope or nature of the bill, nor introduce important elements which were not present during the debate at second reading. There are several other restrictions placed on a committee. As I recently explained on April 28, 1992 in relation to a committee report on the Farm Products Marketing Agencies Bill C-54:
A committee is restricted in its examination in a number of ways. It cannot infringe on the financial initiative of the Crown, it cannot go beyond the scope of the bill as passed at second reading, and it cannot reach back to the parent act to make further amendments not contemplated in the bill no matter how tempting this may be.

Further types of inadmissible amendments are listed in citations 698 to 706 of Beauchesne's sixth edition. Barring these, a committee is completely free to amend a bill in whatever manner it may choose, and to vote for or against any or all of the clauses in the bill as they are submitted for approval to the committee. As the 21st edition of Erskine May explains on page 486:
-notwithstanding the rule which forbids the moving of an amendment which is destructive of the principle of a bill, there is nothing to prevent a committee from negating a clause or clauses, the omission of which may nullify or destroy the bill, and reporting the bill, as amended, to the House; a Committee may also negative
Routine Proceedings
every clause of which the bill is composed, and substitute for those clauses new clauses, if relevant to the bill as read a second time, and otherwise in order.
In the present case, the standing committee elected to delete several clauses of the bill, and in particular several clauses of the proposed Wage Claim Payment Act. In keeping with the explanation found in Erskine May and our own Canadian practices there is nothing which can be found objectionable with this procedure. Consequently, I find that the standing committee report is in order.

Madam Speaker, I wish to bring to the attention of hon. members the fact that we are currently marking Canadian Environment Week, which in 1992 runs from today, June 1 to June 7.
This week gives Canadians an opportunity to ask themselves the question: "What can I do to help the environment?" In the spirit of Environment Week all Canadians, all levels of government and all sectors of society must stop and think about the ways in which they can contribute in preserving and protecting our magnificent country, Canada.
Environment Week is a Government of Canada initiative which funds projects across the country which demonstrate action and participation in Canadian com-

Routine Proceedings
munities. One of the largest initiatives this year is a partnership that has been formed with the Canadian Urban Transit Association. It is offering an enviropass in over 40 cities in Canada to encourage Canadians to use public transportation as an environmentally friendly way to travel.
All of us are urged to make a contribution to Environment Week. For example, we can be vigilant when we are shopping and purchasing consumer products by selecting those products with the least packaging. We can minimize waste, recycle, compost or initiate household practices that will conserve water. The options are really endless.
This year Environment Week and its theme, "It's Up to All of Us", takes on global significance. As we work to improve the environmental state of this great country of Canada, the world's leaders are gathering in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, more commonly called the earth summit.
Canada has played a primary role in organizing this historic conference, and the Canadian delegation, which will be led by the Prime Minister, is providing leadership and solutions to tough economic and environmental concerns.
I invite all hon. members to participate in Environment Week, and their communities. As well, they can participate indirectly in the earth summit by signing the earth flag located at the entrance of the House of Commons today. Upon the signing of the flag it will be delivered to the earth summit in Brazil by Mr. Maury Mason of Earth Day Canada. This flag has already been signed by hundreds of thousands of families and individual Canadians demonstrating Canada's support for the earth summit. This morning the Prime Minister signed this flag.
It is time for all Canadians to make an extra effort to adapt and adopt environmentally responsible behaviour and to make it part of everyday life in the spirit of Environment Week and all year long.
I encourage all Canadians to join in our national environmental efforts this week and every week. I would like to leave the hon. members with a message, which is the earth pledge which states: "Recognizing that people's actions toward nature and each other are the
source of growing damage to the environment and resources needed to meet human needs and to ensure survival and development I pledge to act to the best of my ability to help make the earth a secure and hospitable home for present and future generations".
That is an excellent pledge which I would ask all Canadians to make.

Madam Speaker, today does mark the beginning of Environment Week, which takes place from June 1 to June 7. It is especially important this year as the whole world is looking to the world leaders gathering in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, for the earth summit.
The Rio summit may well be the most important international conference in the history of the world. It has the potential to be the turning point for our environment, resulting in a number of landmark conventions and declarations, and a new global era in the struggle to achieve sustainable development.
Environment Week should be used by the government and Canadians to look very closely at our commitment to saving our rapidly deteriorating environment and to take the necessary measures to halt and reverse the catastrophic impact our actions have had on our world.
The Prime Minister, on behalf of all Canadians, must show in Brazil that Canada is prepared to exercise the leadership it so readily claims. If other nations refuse to accept a convention on climate change with tough targets and timetables Canada must step forward and be the first to sign and invite others to follow.
If others fail to make financial commitments to accomplish agenda 21 then Canada must not fail. On issues of biodiversity, forests, water and poverty, Canada must clearly establish what we believe to be the right path to save the world for future generations and it must be prepared to have the courage to take the first step along that path.

Canada owes it to Canadians and to neighbouring countries to practice what it preaches on all environmental issues.
In matters of environmental protection, we cannot always wait for international agreements to be signed. To harmonize development and environment, Canada must implement effective preventive measures that can be accounted for in front of the whole world.
June 1, 1992

Environment Week is not a time to show off, but to act.

We all have a responsibility, but rather than putting the responsibility solely on individual Canadians we in this House must look to ourselves first and foremost. We must all make the protection of the world our first commitment to Canadians and to those generations to follow. If we as Canadians fail the world in Rio we have a great deal to answer for, and we cannot ask individual Canadians to do what we as their parliamentarians are not prepared to do.

Madam Speaker, it is a pleasure for me to speak today on the beginning of Environment Week in Canada. It is particularly appropriate given the summit in Rio starting later this week.
The minister spoke very well about the need for individuals to do something during Environment Week here in Canada. I take the individual approach to the environment very seriously. I have promoted in my own constituency, as I know members of my caucus have, recycling programs for paper, cans and glass, as well as community clean-ups and other actions that individuals can take on their own.
Despite the fact that individual effort is so important and environment week helps to instil in the individual Canadian a desire to contribute what he or she can to the environment over-all, governments have a much more responsible role to play than encouraging people to recycle bottles and cans and glass and newspapers. Governments have a responsibility to ensure that the inter-governmental agreements that will, in fact, protect the environment from the harm that others can do while we are cleaning up our own backyard are promulgated so that we can stop the destruction of the earth.
As members know, we can burn ethanol in our cars in Canada, but as long as the hundreds of thousands of vehicles in the United States, in Los Angeles for example, are pumping out CO2 emissions into the atmosphere, the efforts we make, as much as it makes us feel comfortable and good, are not going to eventually save the earth.
Routine Proceedings
What we have is a challenge before us, and the conference in Rio is the test of that challenge. We have to reach agreements or the world is in dire jeopardy.
I quote from an excellent book that the round table on the environment and the economy put out earlier this year, called Preserving Our World: A Consumer's Guide to the Brundtland Report by Warner Troyer, in which Mr. Troyer quotes U.S. Supreme Court Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes: "Every man has a right to swing his arms, but that right is circumscribed by the proximity of his neighbour's nose."
Well, the nose is awfully close as the large corporations are swinging their arms at the moment around the world.
The population growth in the world is reaching the point where we can soon no longer feed it. The world's population is projected to top six billion people this year and the carrying capacity for food in this world is estimated to reach about 7.5 billion people. The Brundtland commission report, which talked about the environment and the economy, the need for sustainable development, is very much tied to population growth in the world.
If stabilization of the population in the world is not reached until the year 2035, the total world population will settle at over 10 billion people, very close to the maximum food-carrying capacity that we have and by the year 2065-75 years from now-we could have a population of close to 15 billion people, which, unless something happens quickly, is going to see mass starvation on this planet.
As we know, the root cause of much of the environmental degradation in the world is poverty. Poverty is the greatest single enemy of the environment. The poor and the hungry destroy their environment to ensure their own individual survival. Theirs is an individual effort that is predicated upon the failures of governments to reach agreements that will improve the world's population's poor to a sustainable environment of their own.
I use the opportunity today to impress upon the Minister of the Environment and this government that Canada must take its leadership role seriously in the international community on environmental issues and use the conference in Rio de Janeiro to ensure that the

June 1, 1992

agreements are in place to ensure the protection of the earth.

speakeroldname: Mr. Pierre H. Vincent (Parliamentary Secretary to Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Prime Minister; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I thank you for giving me this opportunity to speak on bill C-80, a most important bill indeed-and I hope that my colleagues from the Bloc Quebecois will be happy with it-as much for children in Quebec as for those throughout Canada. You will understand that Bill C-80 is intended to make all federal transfer payments for children across the country simpler and much, much fairer.
I think that any legislation that undertakes to simplify the handing out of money and simplify the taxation system should be passed as quickly as possible. Full child benefits will hopefully be adopted so that all children can benefit from them as soon as possible.
For some years now, the Government of Canada has been paying special attention to supporting children, making it in fact an ongoing priority. Remember when, in December, the right hon. Prime Minister looked into the United Nations convention which, as a matter of fact, dealt with the rights of the child and which he signed on behalf of Canada.
There is also the Brighter Futures program which, again, is aimed specifically at ensuring a brighter future for the children of Canada and for Canada.
Simplifying the tax system has been a priority for the Conservative government since 1984. When we consider the present system of child benefits and we look at Bill C-80, we realize that today, there are three different ways in which Canadian families receive payments for their dependent children. We all know family allowances, which have been around for 40 or 50 years. We are also familiar with the refundable tax credit and the child credit. These three programs allocate sums of money to families, for their children, at different periods throughout the year.
For many Canadian families this is a complex system. Do I get a cheque in January, March or June? How much will it be? Why am I or am I not eligible? Do I get half the maximum amount, three quarters or nothing at all? So this makes it a complex system, in addition to the other benefits families are entitled to: the goods and services tax credit, the child care expense deduction, parental or maternity benefits under the Unemployment Insurance Act, as well as benefits funded by the federal government and delivered by the provinces.
There are seven or eight different programs to which all Canadian families are entitled. The purpose of Bill C-80 is to get rid of three of these programs and give more money through a single program. We are going to give more money. Over a five-year period, we are talking about an additional $2 billion or more. Consider the three programs that will be eliminated. Family allowances provide $35 per month; the annual credit, $71; the refundable credit, $601 annually; and, depending on the family's economic situation, an additional $213.
June 1, 1992

In future, there will no longer be three periods. There will no longer be three kinds of payments, and family income will replace individual income as the basis for calculating the benefit, to make the system fairer and more equitable. In one family, one spouse may have a fairly high income, while the other spouse may earn less; in another family, both spouses may be earning the same amount. This means that two families with the same total income do not necessarily receive the same amount in family allowances, child credit and refundable child tax credit.
Based on the family's income, the new system will be much fairer and far more equitable. Finally, since payments will be received regularly, low-income families will not be tempted to seek out discounters who often charged outrageous rates to advance the tax credits these families were to receive. By simplifying the system, we are giving families more money, as recommended by various groups in this country.
What does Bill C-80 provide? It provides $1,020 per child and per year, plus $213, if parents or spouses did not claim child care expenses, plus another $75, starting with the third child. This means that low-income families will receive $1,733 for the first child and $1,233 for each subsequent child. Clearly, this makes a big difference for low-income families. However, families with an income of more than $67,000 will receive no child benefits at all. I think it is only fair that high income families should not receive money from the federal government, since they are financially capable of raising their children.
We start at around $26,000. For a net income above $26,000-and I stress, a net income-the tax credit is gradually reduced to zero when the family income reaches $67,000. For a family income below $50,000 per year, the average increase-I say average-will be $250 per child, per year.
Bill C-80 is quite simple and represents an improvement over the current three programs. It provides for fiscal equity and fairness as well as adjustments for inflation. Eighty per cent of the increase resulting from this program will go to families with an income below $40,000.
It is worth stressing the reasons for passing this legislation without undue delays. I repeat, this legislation makes the Canadian fiscal system fairer, since it really
Government Orders
targets low income families who need help raising their children. What is taken into consideration is the family income, not individual income.
It is also a system with more flexibility, and easier to administer, since Canadian families will not have to fill any forms. Calculations will be made automatically by the federal government, based on family income for the year 1991. We want the system in place by January 1, 1993. This means that on January 1, 1993, eligible families, the low income families, will receive a cheque based on their income tax returns for 1991, without having to fill out any kind of form and without having to apply for anything. The amount will be revised after six months, that is to say starting July 1, 1993.
To conclude, I think it is a big step forward for the Government of Canada, already judged number one by the UN, for what it did and continues to do for children and youth. I think we should congratulate the Prime Minister for his leadership in this regard, and for the record of his government over the last eight years. We did our best to simplify the fiscal system and make sure that it benefited low income families while leaving the higher income families to provide for their own children.
Therefore, I urge all members to let this bill pass without undue delays.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):

Madam Speaker, there have been discussions with the representatives of the two opposition parties in respect of the following motion. Pursuant to Standing Order 53(1) I move:
That, in relation to Bill C-81, an act to provide for referendums
on the Constitution of Canada, this House be permitted to waive the
48-hour notice required for the beginning of report stage.
Just by way of explanation, I would like to indicate that the matter of some urgency has to do with the fact that in order to be possible to hold a referendum or plebiscite it requires about three months of preparation time by the chief electoral officer. There is some urgency in getting this through.

Government Orders
There was great co-operation from hon. members last week. The committee met Monday and Tbesday for long hours and indeed Friday, Monday and Tuesday to get the legislation through committee. Hence, but for the fact that the House was adjourned the report would have been tabled and there would have been lots of notice. I do not think there can be any surprises in this instance. It really is a matter of some urgency that we have it on the table, and as I have indicated the two opposition parties have approved.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The House has heard the terms of the motion. There is a one-hour debate with a maximum of 10 minutes for any member who wishes to intervene.

Madam Speaker, once again this government just used an extraordinary procedure, with the blatant complicity of the other two parties in this House, in order to impose closure to parliamentarians.
We just saw a minister of the Crown come before the House and tell its members that the government does not even want to follow the normal rules, the standards rules of debate in this House, but wants to bypass those rules and eliminate the time allowed to members to familiarize themselves with amendments and prepare for debate. This government wants again to put the kibosh on the democratic right of this Parliament to examine properly and with total freedom the referendum bill.
Madam Speaker, you know as well as I that this referendum bill is the most illegitimate and anti-democratic legislation ever seen in the Parliament of a British regime. You know that this bill violates all the democratic rules, that the democratic values that have been so precious to Quebecers, for instance in the 1980s, are going to be violated by this legislation. This Parliament that claims to be a democratic institution now enables the government to steamroll a piece of legislation on the back of Quebec. Indeed, this referendum bill only has one enemy: Quebec. Consequently, we are now witnessing before a House that is certainly not full an outright
violation of the prerogative and the freedom of Parliament to decide but also to debate. I know that the minister talks about the urgency of the matter. How come the minister says that it is urgent to pass the referendum act while his colleague, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs is quite willing to postpone the process for several days? How come the government now wants to ignore the issue of Quebec at the constitutional table and impose an illegitimate and anti-democratic bill that is unworthy of this institution? I am convinced, and you only have to look at the precedents in Great Britain and at the National Assembly in Quebec, that never before has a government had the nerve to table such an antidemocratic piece of legislation. That is why, and I want the members of the government to know that, every time you act in that way you undermine the credibility of the process that you want to undertake. No Quebecer will feel bound by your illegitimate legislation. You can show whatever results you want. You can spend all the millions that you want, but none of us will feel bound by the results of a defective, unworthy and implausible piece of legislation.
When I see the leader of the government show up casually with the complicity of the Liberals and the New Democrats-the word Democrat should be withdrawn- there is no shame-
Madam Speaker, on a point of order, I notice that there are not 20 members in this House. A quorum is not present.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: I have a quorum call.

Call in the members.

And the bells having rung:

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Since we have a quorum, we shall resume debate. The hon. member for Shefford.

Madam Speaker, I thank you for filling up this place. I just wanted to say that Quebec is being bullied into accepting this most shameful bill. One day, each and every hon. member in this House will bitterly regret this debate and this bill on referendums.
June 1, 1992

This bill has been exposed throughout the country. It would not live up to the principles of the most ancient democracies. It looks like a bill passed by a banana republic. I hope hon. members will be ashamed, I hope Quebec members will be embarrassed to see that their government now wants to put the gag on debate, to ignore the usual democratic procedures in order to prevent Parliament from adequately studying and vigorously debating such an important bill.
I do not have to remind you that this bill will never pass the test with regards to justice and fairness. I do not have to remind you that this government is simply misusing Parliament, and there is a price which will have to be paid not only by the Conservatives, but also by their accomplices, the Liberals and the New Democrats, all of whom are joining forces to play a dirty trick on Quebec.
Thank God the Bloc Quebecois is here to expose such a disgraceful tactic. I hope some other members from Quebec will rise, all those who oppose a federal referendum which would be shameful and unfair.
This motion should never have found its way before Parliament. It violates the most fundamental rules of democracy. Consequently, I do hope we will not be the only ones to oppose the motion. We may have different views on the content, on the options available, on a society model, but we have one thing in common: the development of equal and fair democratic rules. Nothing in this bill deals with justice and fairness; the casualness shown by the government is a good example.
We have seen the leader of the government in the House of Commons come up suddenly with this motion, interrupting one of his colleagues to put a gag on debate.
The Parliament and the small club of old parties which can play all their little games here, but it is in the field that we will find the truth and settle their score. The price to pay for this violation of democracy and justice is enormous.
Government Orders
The marks of conscription haunted this Parliament for many years. The memories of that debate are nothing compared to what awaits members who are accomplices to such an arrogant and undemocratic action. Therefore, during the next few minutes, I dare hope that other Quebecers, at least the democratic ones, will find out that a crime against history is being committed here.
It is obvious that this motion should not be passed, that we cannot accept the way the government wants to steamroller it through. If federalists in this House are so self-confident, why are they scared of the debate? Why are they scared of the usual rules? What do they want to hide? What do they want to avoid?
It is obvious that what we are seeing here is a shady deal, a political operation with a single goal: to save the skin of the Prime Minister of Canada at all costs-
Even if it means to trample on Quebec.

-at all costs and to trample on Quebec with the federal steamroller.
That is what the government tried to do to us on a Monday afternoon. It will be a black Monday in the history of this Parliament and I hope that this government realizes the extent of its action. I hope that my Liberal friends who I thought were democratic-I see the hon. member for Saint-Denis and I am sure he will oppose Parliament preventing debate on the referendum bill, because he too knows that this referendum will not be valid if it is-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The ten-minute period is now over.

Madam Speaker, I listened to the hon. member with great interest. In my caucus, we had a lot of discussions about this issue.

With the background that I have it did not take a long discussion to understand how we would vote on this motion. We have heard a lot of speeches, and we are going to hear more on this motion.

Government Orders
I am going to make a short speech. We are going to go for the motion. We think it is right. We think it is proper.

Madam Speaker, the rhetoric of our colleagues from the Bloc notwithstanding, I really do not have much difficulty with this motion. It is asking the House to waive the normal 48 hours that are required for the beginning of report stage. It is not cutting back or reneging in any way on the ability to debate the issue of this motion.
Standing Order 53(1) states very simply that:
In relation to any matter that the government considers to be of an urgent nature, a Minister of the Crown may, at any time when the Speaker is in the Chair, propose a motion to suspend any Standing or other Order of this House relating to the need for notice and to the hours and days of sitting.
My colleagues and I in the New Democratic Party have supported in principle the provisions of the enabling legislation for a non-binding referendum. This is an issue which is of an urgent nature. This is an issue which is of grave national concern.
Speaking on behalf of my colleagues, I want to say that we feel that, although we have some concerns about the details of the legislation, fundamentally the people of this country should be allowed to be heard in helping to determine the future of this land.
Although we have some specific problems with the bill, we have no concern about bringing that bill at this time back from report stage to debate some of the amendments, some of the recommendations and some of the proposed changes, hopefully to strengthen the legislation and to provide an opportunity for the people of Canada to have a voice in determining the future of this land.
We will be supporting this notice of motion by the government.

Madam Speaker, I listened to the member for Shefford earlier today. I cannot figure out where he is coming from.
In my first year in this city back in 1980,1 worked with the member for Shefford. At that time, he worked almost night and day seven days a week campaigning for Canada. He at that time was a very effective member in making sure that those of us who wanted to keep this
country together had all of his energy and all of his support.
I also remember in 1984 when he was the minister responsible for fitness and amateur sport in this country. He travelled the country speaking on behalf of not just Quebec, but every region of this country. This was, of course, an Olympic year when he was very proud to speak about the athletes and the people who represented us in this country.
Today I listened to his speech and where he talked about a bill that is being put before this House, if I understood him correctly, he said that this bill was going to "skin" Quebec, this was going to be the rape of Quebec.
This is something that many of us have a tough time figuring out when we hear the Bloc Quebecois coming out with words like this. There are a lot of people in the province of Quebec who still believe in Canada.
Where are they today?

I am talking about the people of Quebec. There are a lot of federalists in the province of Quebec. It seems to me that when you talk about frustrating a referendum process, you almost insult the intelligence not only of the federalists but of all Quebecers.
It seems to me that your opposing this referendum process is sort of contradictory to what you have basically been proposing in this House since you have decided to become a separatist. Quite frankly, a lot of my constituents in Toronto have a difficult time with this Bloc Quebecois operation.
They have not seen anything yet.

We were elected to come to this Chamber. I do not just try to speak here for Toronto or for Ontario. I try to speak and try to make sure that we work on legislation that is for all regions of the country.
Why you want to work at dismantling this country is really beyond most Canadians' imagination. Why do you want to sort of systematically, like this morning, try to devise ways of frustrating this Parliament when there is so much economic pain out there and the pain in the economy is as important to the people of Quebec as it is to the people of Newfoundland, Toronto or wherever in this country?
June 1, 1992

The government has the right to put forward this 48-hour motion today. We in the Liberal Party have supported this. This is not a surprise attack.
I would ask the member to think back as to how and who elected him to the Parliament of Canada. They elected him when he first came here to speak for Canada, to speak for Quebec in Canada and he fought for Quebec in Canada for many years. All of a sudden he has become a turncoat. Why he has done this is beyond my imagination, but as far as I am concerned this is counterproductive and it is going nowhere.

Madam Speaker, I want to just add a few words under this rule 53(1). The rule was put in the Standing Orders for certain special reasons. Certainly if you are talking about the fate of the country and/or Constitution and referendum, and I cannot think of a much more important issue-and I think it is the first time it has been used under the Standing Orders-if there ever was a reason to use it, it is certainly when the state of the country and/or the Constitution is at play.
I listened with a great deal of interest to the hon. member for Broadview-Greenwood. Without getting into a dog fight with other members individually here, I thought he made very good points. As he spoke I looked in the index. Of course as the hon. member for Shefford knows, he is still in the index as the Honourable Jean Lapierre. Perhaps he would like to correct the index at some time to eliminate the honourable which means that he was a member of Her Majesty's Privy Council.
On this issue, no one has been caught by surprise. There has been constitutional discussion ad nauseam. The country is absolutely fed up with the fact that we cannot seem to resolve something that is fundamental to every Canadian. Even though it does not excite every Canadian from day to day, it is fundamental. So it is time to come to grips with it.
I firmly believe that we should have this referendum legislation as a tool for the government to use in its way. I agree with the NDP. There are parts of the bill that personally I have some problems with. I may try to move an amendment or so if they are in order. I know this rule certainly speeds up the necessity to get your amendments before the table before time runs out. If there was ever a reason to use this, this is a reason where the national issue of the country is at stake.
Government Orders
When I stop to think of what the hon. minister of intergovernmental affairs has tried to do over months of constitutional discussions and then to read in the papers that the deadlock is on a dead Senate which should not even exist as far as I am concerned, an appointed body is an anachronism of history, to think that in effect that should be the stumbling block is something that I just cannot rationalize. I believe, when the time is proper, after consultations are over and after the first ministers and/or the phones are busy this week, and/or/if the negotiations continue on June 9, that the government should get the referendum bill in place. I would like to know if Canadians even want the Senate regardless of what state of reform. If you are going to reform it then okay, we get into all the arguments that everyone has written books about since I went to high school and certainly since I wrote my first political science paper on the Senate way back in 1950. There has not been a new thing said about Senate reform since then and even years before.
I think the fundamental question is, even in Alberta, to see if the public wants the Senate by putting it directly to the people. The leaders have had their chance to try to resolve the issues. In effect the political elite have been locked in rooms for days and weeks as the conferences have gone across the country from sea to sea and, as they have gone from sea to sea, they still have not come up with the consensus.
I say let us trust the people and put it to the people. This referendum bill allows separate amendments. I did not like that in the bill initially and frankly had some suspicions, but maybe the wisdom of some of the government advisers is obviously a lot better than mine. It may be that if we get this bill in place we could use it individually in different areas. Certainly there is one for the Senate.
I am going to conclude, having had a chance to speak on this motion. I may have more difficulty speaking in a tightly confined debate on the bill when we launch into it, I gather, tomorrow.
This will not be received with great favour and it may be misinterpreted in many parts I suppose, but I believe this whole question of inherent right of self-government of the aboriginals with the implication of a third level of government, federal, provincial, and aboriginal, is something the people should have a chance to decide, including the aboriginals of course, before we lock ourselves into a system that will be paralysed from A to Z.

Government Orders
Let us get on with the referendum bill. Let us try to resolve things by consultation, but I am afraid the consultations have produced so little. I quite understand some of the empathy of the Bloc Quebecois although obviously, I do not share its objectives. I do not think there is going to be the fundamental offer that is necessary from consultations.
Even in Quebec, it would be interesting to see what they think about the Senate. Certainly Quebec has a very real interest in the question of the aboriginals. We have already seen what the Cree in a united way have been able to do to affect certain parts of Quebec. Both of those questions should be put to the people where the political leaders have not been able to resolve them.
Madam Speaker- [Translation]
It is to remind you, Madam Speaker, that I have been sitting here since 10 o'clock this morning and that I have asked the right to speak before the four previous speakers, two of whom were not-

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: The hon. member for Richelieu should appreciate the fact that whereas members from all sides of this House want to speak on this motion, as of now one member of his group has already had the opportunity to speak, as well as one other independent member. I think it is perfectly normal that members from other parties have the opportunity to express themselves, and he should leave it to the incumbent of the Chair to recognize the members for debate, that being its job. The hon. member for Churchill has the floor.

I voted against the government's bill in second reading because I feel it is a flawed piece of legislation.
I looked at it in terms of some of the major concerns that I have. I believe that the government made no attempt to resolve the issues that I have. I look at this legislation and believe that it does not provide for a fair referendum and I will go into that in a few minutes.
Having said that, I have no problem with the debate starting tomorrow. I think that the earlier we get into this debate, the more we discuss it, the more the public is aware of what is actually in the legislation, the better it is for all Canadians.
I believe that as Canadians see the legislation and hear the debate on the legislation they too will be concerned about that legislation.
I have had the opportunity, as have other members of this House, to read the report from the committee, to see the bill as it is reported. I have had the opportunity to prepare my amendments as are required under the rules of the House. Other members who may have concerns with that bill have had the same opportunity. Having said that, I have no problem with the motion to waive the 48-hour notice period for that.
As I did indicate earlier, the bill itself is not just a piece of legislation that enables a referendum. Unfortunately, it basically establishes a Conservative agenda for how elections should be run in this country.
It gets rid of any real spending limits. It allows outside interests with the biggest dollar to have the biggest bang.
In other words, if you take a look at this legislation and compare it with the normal election laws of this country, you see it is not the same. However if you take a look at this legislation and see how things are run south of the border in the United States, you see that what we are doing is Americanizing the electoral laws of this country.
We know there are no effective limits on spending in the United States. We see what has happened to then-democracy as a result of that, where less than 50 per cent of the people vote for the election of the most powerful person on our globe, the President of the United States, where large amounts of money must be raised by each and every member of the House of Representatives. What has happened over the years is that people running for Congress actually have full-time staff paid for by Congress who go out and fund raise. That is what has happened to the American system.
June 1, 1992

A lot of us, as I said earlier, could support a fair referendum bill. I have to ask if aboriginal Canadians have concerns about this legislation, where are they going to find the dollars to go out and spend the $10 million that would be allowed under this legislation? If the women of Canada have concerns, where are they going to raise that money? They do not control the boardrooms of our nation yet.
What we have here is a piece of legislation which is not looking at fairness. It is not looking at how we should best bring this country together. What we have here is a way that people will feel they have been bought during the election campaign.
There are absolutely no limits on paid advertising, but who has the money to buy that? Not most individual Canadians. Not the homeless. Not the poor. Not the people who will be concerned on an individual basis. It will be the corporate elite of this land. Someone once said: "Well, that won't happen in this country. The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Mazankowski that Bill C-80, an act to amend the Income Tax Act, to enact the Children's Special Allowances Act, to amend certain acts in consequence thereof and to repeal the Family Allowances Act, be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Economics envelope.

Madam Speaker, I rise to respond to the government's Bill C-80, which is a bill to amend the Income Ihx and in fact do away with family allowances and set out a new pattern of child benefits.
Before dealing specifically with the legislation I would like to take this opportunity to review the way our party is approaching social policy as given to us by this government since 1984.
June 1, 1992

One academic writer has described it as social policy by stealth. I would just like to support that analysis. The way this government has sought to change the major pieces of legislation in this countiy governing social policy has been to do it through the back door, to do it in debates in which the Canadians following Parliament do not understand just how fundamental the changes being made are, as they are not being properly announced.
For example, who would have thought that Bill C-80, an act to amend the Income Thx Act, in fact contained major changes in the way we treat children in this country? It was not brought in as a new policy dealing with child benefits. It was not brought in by the Minister of National Health and Welfare, who is responsible for children in this country.
It was brought in by the Minister of Finance as a ways and means motion. It was brought in through the budget as a budgetary motion. It was not presented clearly to Canadians as an act to change the way we deal with children.
We can go back through several pieces of legislation, particularly in the last two years, in which the government has sought to change the fundamental way in which we built up the social security system in this country by moving through the back door.
Let me give three examples. The most famous example, used and perhaps decried by all the social policy committees across this country, was Bill C-69 which was the first act to cut back transfer payments to the provinces. That was a battle in which the groups opposed to these changes, the groups involved with the delivery of medicare services in the provinces, post-secondary education and social services, realized too late in the process, in fact this bill had gone to the Senate, how fundamental the changes were that were occurring to them.
In the second last budget, in 1991, the government presented changes along the same lines and called them very simply Bill C-20 and Bill C-32. These again were considered to be amendments to the fiscal arrangements act and were done in a very quiet way.
This time the government took this not to the social policy committee or the health committee but to the finance committee, which is the last place social policy groups are used to going to find out what changes are being made in dealing with things like medicare, post-secondary education and social assistance measures under
Government Orders
the Canada Assistance Plan. All these measures were done quietly.
However, this time the groups were notified, not by the government or by the House of Commons but by the opposition, this party, to come out and share their views on the impact that Bill C-69 was already having on the system. Day after day, we heard these groups say: "Do you not realize what you are doing to the social fabric of this country? Do you not realize how much you are undermining people's confidence in government to help them?"
That is a very important message when groups-not fringe groups but groups representing doctors, nurses, practitioners of all kinds in the health care system, representing regional governments in this country, major actors responsible for hundreds of millions of dollars- come forward, not to whine as the the government would say but to say to people: "Listen, you have just done enough cutbacks and we need to be protected".
In this budget we see another change. It is dealing with child benefits. I did some research on this, this is not hyperbole. This white paper, entitled The Child Benefit, is the shortest white paper presented in the history of any government in Canada. The total amount of money it was dealing with was $4.5 billion. In 14 short pages the Government of Canada announced its most major changes to the way that we deal with children, $4.5 billion was summarized in graphs and a few cliches in 14 pages.
Since that was introduced in March of this year the government has laid low. It has not produced any subsequent documents. It has not prepared the public for any discussion. It has not announced anywhere that this is going to legislative committee for discussion. It is going to put us on hurry up because it needs these amendments made to the Income Tkx Act soon, if they are going to take effect next year.
We see here not only a push on other fronts, which we find very difficult to deal with these days, but on the most basic of things. If done properly, and if people take the time to think of the consequences dealing with children, we could have a worth-while discussion in committee in this House and across the country. No, this government simply wants to get on with it and make these changes before Canadians wake up and realize what is happening to them.

June 1, 1992
