One of the fundamentals of social policy in this country, particularly since the Second World War, is that the Canadian government should seek as many ways as possible to support family life. The number of vehicles available to the government to do that in a federal system are limited.
However, through gradual changes in family law and through changes right after the Second World War in some of the UI provisions, and also through the children's special allowances act and family allowances, we began to develop a system in which the Government of Canada said to each and every family: "We understand that what you are doing is very important for society. We cannot always give you a lot of money but we understand that no matter what your background, who you are, what your husband does, all these other things, we will give you a small amount of money each month to help out".
For some families that is a very real amount, $35 per child still buys a week's worth of groceries and basics, it still buys a few books, it still buys the occasional treat, it still alleviates some of the tensions between men, women and families, and it does not make a statement about income levels. It is very important that in the way in which we create social policies that we do not make statements on class and do not make the assumption that because one income-earner in a family is well-off that everyone else in the family is well-off. There are subtle ways to state that we understand that in your own private lives this small amount of money may be of some help to you.
The government has decided, through the continuation of a social policy by stealth, that the principle of reaching out to each family no longer applies. It will seek to target those families which it thinks need the most.
In some respects the targeting philosophy is very popular in this country. People are wondering in times of tight budgets and high deficits if targeting is not the proper strategy. Any political party worth its salt does not just look at the past policies but looks into the future and seeks to make sure that it is being as responsive as possible.
The underlying fault with so-called targeting is that it lets too many people off the hook. We do not often like to make these comparisons between Canada and the United States, the rhetoric of targeting, the rhetoric of cutbacks, the rhetoric of telling people they must do with less is strictly a part of the ideological thrust of the right in America. The price Americans are paying in their cities and among their youth is far greater than we ever want to pay. That is because the American strategy has always been to claim targeting, rather than the reality of reaching out to too few to be of help.
One test which we would like to apply in examining the child benefits package is to apply the litmus test of the government itself. The government's litmus test is twofold. First, it is there to help the very poorest of families to withstand changes taking place in their lives, and second, those people who are not being helped do not really need the help.
Let us examine the first principle. The very poorest of Canadians either fall under the Indian Act and represent about 400,000 status Indians living on reserves across the country, the largest proportion of those are under 25 years old and a good many of those are under 18, or are covered by the Canadian Assistance Plan and are living on either provincial or municipal social assistance programs. That varies of course from province to province and city to city. It is hard to generalize from here all the characteristics of those systems.
This particular child benefits package deliberately does not speak to the question of those very poor families who are living on social assistance. It is deemed that there are measures in place to look after those people but the reality is that because of the cutbacks, legislated through Bills C-69, C-20 and C-32, the fundamentals of our system for dealing with poor families have been undermined.
If we examine the literature from the social sciences, certainly throughout the 20th century in North America and back to 19th century industrial England, the whole thesis is that to help the poor we need a basket of programs or a combination of programs to support them, not only through cash but in a number of other ways.
In Canada we have taken many different initiatives. However, we will just isolate three or four of them. First, we will deal with housing. This government has continued its cutbacks in social housing and co-operative

housing to the extent that this year CMHC has all but left the field.
Second, we will look at education. The cutbacks to these different programs, to education and training, is dramatic and the access of young people to training is almost nil.
Third is the question of nutrition and health care at a young age. Fundamental to healthy family life is a healthy community and healthy children.
When you undermine those basic principles, when you take away the support structures, and then come in at the end with a little bit of cash it is very deceptive.
One academic made a presentation to us that struck me, and I think will strike me for many years to come. She said that in her professional estimate the amount of money withdrawn from the health care system by measures of this government from 1984 to 1993, the end of the next fiscal year, is going to be as high as $43 billion.
If we examine those measures that I talked about before, at what is happening in medicare as it deals with children, in pre-natal care, what is happening in housing, and what is happening in education, we see that there is an emerging crisis here. When the government makes another announcement dealing with family benefits we must expect that the cash put on the table is somehow going to begin to compensate for what is taken away.
There is a theory among some social scientists, particularly among conservative economists, that the problem with the poor is that they do not have money. Therefore the simple solution is to give them money and the poverty will begin to end.
It is not so simple.
In a community in which roads are run down or property that people rent is not kept up, along with other little things which do not work, the cash presented by the federal government will have minimal impact in creating a healthy community.
As a result of the emergence of CAP and the strategy of this government that the welfare poor should be more subject to provincial assistance than to federal assistance the federal government made the decision that it would not change the benefits to the non-working poor, that is to say those people who do not have income as defined under the Income Tax Act.
Government Orders
That is a brutal blow. In fact it is not clear at this time whether the new benefits package which is paid monthly for the child will be given freely to these individuals without the province taking recourse because it represents such a substantial change in the way that the cash comes in.
If the federal government and the minister of health are seeking to change the way that people receive money the least he can do in negotiating with the provincial ministers of social services is to guarantee that the money he is providing for these people will not be used against them in the determination of provincial levels of social assistance.
Possibly that is difficult for the House to accept, but that question has not yet been publicly answered by any of the ministers across this country.
In terms of the test of helping out the very poorest there is no change in the position of these families. They will not receive any extra moneys.
The second question is whether the cut-off level is realistic. Are people going to begin to receive less money from the federal government at a level at which we sitting here think they can get by with?
As part of its strategy the government, and probably quite appropriately in this case, has been most generous with families earning between $20,000 and $30,000.
I want to stop here and point out one subtle change. Again this is where as an opposition critic I become furious with this government. If it is talking openly with people, how many Canadians realize that now the question no longer concerns individual income but family income?
How many people now realize that in order to obtain benefits under the child benefit process they must be able to show the income of both people?
The government has decided that if the family income is in excess of $30,000 a family should receive minimum assistance under this plan. The calculations, if you follow the child benefit package as presented in this in-depth 14-page report, are very difficult to follow. By most measures the average family with both spouses in the home working will receive an additional $4 a month if its family income is about $30,000. This continues right straight through to $50,000. Then once they get between $50,000 and $100,000 by a sliding scale, people begin to receive less.

June 1, 1992
Government Orders
Let us deal with the middle income families. The average family income in Canada according to Statistics Canada is about $51,000. That means that the government's cut-off point is below the average, which by definition means that the average family is going to receive little or no benefit.
I cannot think of any circumstances under which an extra $4 a month will fundamentally change the relationship between a family and a child. In what ways can a parent substantially change the way a child saves, a child buys clothes or a child is fed with $4 extra a month?
That is as insulting as the 37-cent increase given to seniors on their last senior citizens' cheque. That is the type of sleight of hand or social policy by stealth that this party wishes to challenge on the floor of the House of Commons as being unfair to most Canadians.
The government projects itself as being of great help to children. It has national press conferences. The minister was quick to tell me that he had been out to Winnipeg North Centre and understood and saw the poverty in my constituency.
Families are trying very hard, particularly families of new Canadians with incomes of $30,000 to $35,000 and families with two people working at the minimum wage and working overtime, which are not uncommon. How can we say to them that basically we think they make enough and do not need the help of the government? This is an important part of our society. The government is no longer willing to provide them with any increases that take into account the increased pressure that they are feeling.
As members of Parliament we would have to be deaf and dumb to say that we do not hear constantly from constituencies about how tough it is to make ends meet. Nobody has a nickel to spare.

Madam Speaker, I am very happy that my colleague did call quorum on my behalf. I need an audience for such an important speech.

I would just like to continue with the analysis of low income families, particularly new Canadians. As I started to note, the message goes out from the government that if they are making $30,000 or $35,000 a year as a couple they can look after their children and do not need its help.
We can take that as a stark contrast with the recognition in Quebec, for example, of how fundamentally important support for children is at the outset and in the continuation. If we want to have a healthy society, we must give out the signal constantly that there is a government that cares. We would not use public relations to overcome the fact that we are not really spending any money.
In fact we on this side of the House could accept a policy framework which stated that due to the bankruptcy of the government all we can do at this time is give an extra $4 a month to people earning $40,000 a year but that as money comes in families are our first priority. That could be accepted.
They should not pretend something different. For example, officials proudly informed members of Parliament in a briefing that most Canadians would be receiving a higher monthly payment under this system than ever before. They failed to add in the concluding statement that most Canadian families would be receiving less annually. That is a diversionary tactic which just goes to the heart of the lack of credibility of the social policy of this government. As such, instead of stepping forward to help children, this government has in fact stepped back in a very dramatic fashion.
June 1, 1992

Let us not only consider what I have to say and what this party has to say. Let us stop and listen to what other people have said.
It is not as if all of a sudden the government, starting in January in preparation for its February budget, heard about child poverty. What happened to the national day care study which set out a very elaborate process for working toward day care? It has disappeared; it is forgotten. What about the Senate committee that worked for months on poverty and came out with several options for the government to consider? It is forgotten. What happened to the subcommittee on child poverty and its report just before Christmas with very specific recommendations dealing, for example, with prenatal care? It is forgotten.
The government has forgotten every major initiative it initiated and for which it sought public support for. It took a very minor step forward yet claimed it was looking after the basic income problems of children. I believe that is the type of disrespect for Canada and Canadians that people have begun to resent.
A number of groups has come forward but I would just like to deal with what one group said in its critique of the new child tax benefit in the 1992 budget. It was prepared by Ken Battle, president of the Caledon Institute of Social Policy.
We should not only be concerned with what we tried to do in the past through universal programs or with the present and what this government is doing, but we should look into the future. What is social policy for children going to look like in 1997? Let me quote: "Like the current child benefit system the new system will only be partially indexed, which means the benefits will fall steadily in value as the years go by. The federal government has already siphoned off an estimated $3.5 billion out of child care benefits for 1986 through 1991 by the physically powerful and politically invisible mechanisms of partial deindexation".
Ken Battle continues: "For example, a welfare couple with two children, one under seven and one between seven and seventeen, will get $2,253 from the new child tax benefit in 1993. By the year 2000 their benefit will have declined to $1,862, which is $391 or 17 per cent less than in 1993. Their cumulative loss of child benefits will amount to a hefty $1,532".
Government Orders
In other words, they start out with a system which is really tight now. They put in the deindexing provision, and gradually, gradually families find it more difficult. However, they wash their hands of it and say: "That was done many years ago", and they hope people forget about it.
We have reached a point where we should re-establish our commitment to certain fundamental beliefs. The Liberal Party of Canada built up the social policy network we have starting in the 1930s, continuing after World War II and through the 1950s and 1960s, and culminating in income security for seniors and medicare for the nation. This was a longstanding commitment. As a caucus and as a party we have recently reconfirmed these views.
I would like to quote from a recent motion of the Liberal Party: "The Liberals believe that Canada must remain a society committed to both greater economic opportunity and to social justice for all its people, and that to be productive members of the work force individual Canadians must be equipped with the necessary tools for life and work". It continues: "They must be healthy, well nourished, well educated and well trained to achieve their own economic success. We are committed to meeting these goals for Canadians".
If we want this generation, the hundreds of thousands of children and each of the age cohorts, to move in to a more productive life, we have to start with income support to the family which adds up to more than $4 a month. We have to provide pre-natal care. We have to make sure there is day care, particularly in our large cities. There is no reason we have to get ourselves into a comer by plastering the whole country with day care spaces and day care facilities when the need varies from one region to the other, but we have to start. This party has never, ever vacillated on support for national day care.
There are thousands upon thousands of families, particularly in the big cities, right across this country who cannot survive without two people working. They cannot have two people working unless they are sure their children are being looked after. Recent statistics indicate that the number of days women miss work every year is going up because in the end they are the ones responsible for their children. This is what happens when we do not have a proper system.

June 1, 1992
Government Orders
We have to make sure there are summer programs for them. In our city we could not get that because Challenge 92 was too small, an issue that is not discussed here. We have to make sure when we talk about training that it is not just UI based. Aboriginal youth and women returning to the work force for the first time in years must have access to these programs. We have to make sure of these things. We cannot take them for granted.
This program has dropped support from age 18 to age 17. What do students who are going to university do? They want people to be trained. They do not want them to be bankrupt. Yet the bill is totally silent on it. They take a small piece of the pie and try to parade it as being as big as possible.
In the meantime people start getting their cheques and are happy. This government hopes to keep them happy for six months before the election comes. However, the husband and wife will begin to compare what they are really getting out of it. When the major spouse's income, usually the man's, drops dramatically because of changes in the Income Thx Act and another cheque arrives for $200, $300 or $400 a month, people are going to be confused. At first they will think they are ahead. Then they will realize they have been subjected, at their own expense, to one of the biggest con jobs in social policy seen in Europe and in North America for many years to come.
This is the reason we call upon the government to take the initiative in the legislative committee which we are hopefully headed for very shortly. When we reach the legislative committee hopefully it is not only opposition members asking for different witnesses. Government members themselves should take the initiative. There are many questions left unanswered, but they should be put on the table now and the government should be asked to respond to the problem.
For example, let me refer to some of the questions which are unanswered in the legislation. First, is this new money or tinkering with forecasted growth?
The Conservative government's white paper on child benefits states: "Over the next five years the child tax benefit will provide almost $2.1 billion in increased child assistance". However, there is some doubt that this
projected increase is new money but merely the five-year accumulative increase that would have occurred to the existing child benefits system. Preliminary estimates show that between 1986 and 1991 family allowances payments grew by approximately $275 million. For the same five-year period the refundable child tax credit grew by approximately $750 million.
The government should show the committee that the total growth forecast for the three existing child benefits exceeds or is not similar to the one being proposed in the new program.
Second, there is a number of constitutional implications. Both the current deal being discussed through the media and the report of the special joint committee on a renewed Canada contained many ideas on social policy. Is this legislation consistent with what is happening in Alberta and Quebec, or are they issues that need to be resolved before the legislation is passed?
Third, there is the erosion of child benefits. The proposed child benefit is indexed to increases in inflation less 3 per cent. This partial deindexation will cause the benefits to decrease steadily in value as the years go by. It was the process of partial indexation that allowed the Conservative government to take approximately $3.5 billion out of the child benefits system between 1986 and 1991.
How does this government intend to monitor and adjust the levels of benefit and the income threshold so that the value is not eroded over time by inflation?
Finally, we come to the major point of the discussion. At this time in every major city in this country we are facing a crisis, where youth are unemployed at the rate of at least 20 per cent, and where there are pockets of youth unemployment and student unemployment far higher than that. We have people between the ages of 16 and 25 making critical decisions which are destructive because of their lack of opportunity to do things positively. We have students and young people turned away from training programs because of a lack of funding. We have the group which most needs help finding that the national government has run out of cash to help them. You have to stop and think of that, what it means to say that you have run out of cash to help the young people.
June 1, 1992

My argument is that if this government took proper time to consult with Canadians and if it asked them for a priority, income support for children, for families, for youth would be the number one priority.
We take for granted the phenomenal progress we have made in dealing with the elderly in Canada from the mid-1960s to the late 1980s. Between housing programs, an effective medicare system, an effective community health-based system dealing with questions of nutrition, special programs like New Horizons, and basic income support programs, we could quite literally begin to think that we had dealt with the issue of the elderly.
Now we are faced with another social crisis, the strategic underpinnings of which are quite clear. Every child in this country deserves support. Every child in this country deserves an opportunity of a home, the opportunity to be fed, the opportunity to have an education, the opportunity to walk down the street without being faced with a gang, and the opportunity to make a choice of going to university or a community college without being bankrupted. When children sense that the people on top, the generation that has gone before them that has reaped so beautifully from a generous system, and I include myself here, when people like myself say: "No more, there's no money for you because we won't pay the taxes, we won't structure a government, we won't set priorities"-all these reasons-"we can't help you", then I say to you that that will be a sad day in this country. It will mark the beginning of the end of confidence in the government system among the veiy young.
It will start as soon as we begin to pick and choose among the families we want to help. I urge this government to use a legislative committee, not to ram through an amendment to the Income Tax Act of Canada, but to stop and to say: "All right, let's hear from some important groups, let's have the government members bring in some of these groups, let's have the opposition parties bring in some groups. Let's talk about what it costs to bring up a child nowadays; let's talk about what it costs to keep a child off the streets. Let's talk about the cost, and the Solicitor General can tell us about that, to have an aboriginal youth in a western Canadian prison, what it is
Government Orders
costing the Government of Canada to set up aboriginal women's centres across this country because of past
policies".
We say to ourselves: "Is this what we are going to be spending our money on for the next generation or are we going to systematically seek out a different way of doing things?"
As with any policy, does any one party have all the wisdom? The answer is no. The parliamentary system has tried to wrestle with the questions of child poverty for the last five years. We have had reports, we have had expert witnesses, and again and again we have walked away from the recommendations of these people.
This is our last chance. If the final product of this Parliament is going to be known as Bills C-69, C-20, C-32 and C-80 as the so-called building blocks for a new social policy in the country, I think we are going to have exactly the opposite effect.
In fact, we are going to end up with a system which is so demoralized, actualized, bankrupt of ideas and money, it is going to take us another generation to regain the confidence of the young people. I thank you for the opportunity to participate in this debate and I look forward to a lengthy discussion in legislative committee.

Madam Speaker, it is with some resignation that I stand to debate the government's child benefits legislation. We see this at the end of a long line of attacks on Canada's social programs, in particular, attacks on Canada's poor children.
If we look back to November 29, 1989, we will remember this House voted unanimously for the resolution moved by the then leader of the New Democratic Party, that it express its concern for the more than one million Canadian children currently living in poverty and seek to achieve the goal of eliminating poverty among Canadian children by the year 2000. On that day the Prime Minister, every member of cabinet, and all of the members representing the government voted in favour of that motion to end child poverty by the year 2000.

June 1, 1992
Government Orders
On many occasions in the past the Prime Minister talked about social programs as a sacred trust, as programs which would be enhanced and maintained for all Canadians into the future.
Last December the Prime Minister signed the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child which tied and bound Canada by international agreement to support children in Canada, to maintain them and provide for their needs. In that context, in signing that convention, the Prime Minister committed himself and his government to placing children as the first goal on Canada's resources, the first goal in good times and in bad times.
It may be we are in bad times. I think those millions of Canadians who are on welfare, the over one million Canadians who are unemployed, would agree that we are in bad times. The Prime Minister committed himself to provide for children in good times and in bad times. Now we see the implications of that. Actions quite clearly speak louder than words.
We are discussing today the government's plan to address or respond to the concerns of Canada's poor children. Critics have made it clear that the government is not fulfilling its obligations to Canada's children, to Canada's future. No social groups working in the field support the changes to the legislation, to child benefit programs which this government is proposing. All those organizations working on behalf of poor children, on behalf of the poor, who understand the poor, who live with them and work with them every day loiow there is a need for a major shift in government economic and social policy. This has been clear to the government over many years and the government continues in this same course, this course which has served the interests and concerns of Canada's poor so badly.
Lest we think things are not so bad, let us be clear about the numbers of people that we are dealing with here. Let us ask the question: Is Canada's economy working? It is not working for the over 863,000 children who are welfare recipients; 37.8 per cent of all welfare recipients are children.
It is not working for the 2.3 million welfare recipients in Canada, the 1.3 million unemployed in Canada, and it is not working for the over one million children in poverty in Canada. This economy, this country, is not working for millions and millions of Canadians.
Lest we think much is to be achieved by this child benefit proposal by the government, let us look at some of the things that have been said about it by analysts who are not tied to the government, nor tied to any other political party.
Ken Battle, who used to the director of the National Council on Welfare, the advisory agency to the government's own health and welfare department, said in response to these proposals that the working poor families are falling deeper and deeper below the poverty line. He said that the federal proposals are designed to pretend to fight child poverty while at the same time making sure that middle and some upper income families get larger benefits. He talked about partial indexation. As we know this program, as with so many government programs, will only be indexed to inflation over 3 per cent. He said that deindexation is a fiscally powerful and politically invisible mechanism that allows the government to siphon money from social programs.
Prior to the introduction of this legislation, Canada's average families have seen their social programs from this government reduced by about half of what they were seven years ago. Through various approaches this government has cut family benefits dramatically, as I say, to about half. It has killed the old income tax deduction for dependent children and brought in a tax credit which is worth far less, now just standing at $71 a child. It did not index benefits fully for inflation, as I said.
Year after year these benefits will continue to shrink as they have done for the last seven, eight, nine years. This means that the poor will remain poor. We are not solving that problem. Indeed, the minister responsible, the Minister of National Health and Welfare, has said that in spite of his government's and his own vote in favour of the resolution to eliminate child poverty by the year 2000 only two to three years ago, now that commitment to end child poverty is an unrealizable dream.
For the over one million children living in poverty, it is a necessity to get out of poverty, to break that poverty cycle. For the government minister responsible for the support for poor children to say that it is an unrealizable dream is to give up the fight before it has begun. Indeed, in order to deal with the problems that poor children face, the minister needs to fight tooth and nail against his own cabinet ministers to ensure that economic and
June 1, 1992

Government Orders
social policies are changed in this country to support those children.
During various briefings that have taken place, Department of National Health and Welfare officials have indicated that children whose family income is derived from social assistance and from unemployment insurance will be no better off under the new system than under the old. In other words, the poorest of Canada's children will not be addressed by these changes to child benefits.
For someone earning less than $10,000, the family income coming from child benefits will stay exactly the same as it was before. Not one extra penny is being added to the poorest of Canada's poor children. The only changes which take place add about $500 to families earning up to about $30,000. In other words, it is about $1.30 a day for poor families and lower income families in Canada.
That is not going to deal with the one million children who go to bed hungry at night. One dollar and twenty-five cents a day per family is not going to address that concern. Indeed, as the government's own officials have indicated, it is not even intended to deal with that problem. As I have said, the government itself is not even committed any longer to eliminating child poverty by the end of the decade.
In the process of introducing these changes, and an issue not mentioned once by the government spokesperson presenting this bill who, as has been noted, has a finance portfolio, not a health and welfare portfolio, we have had this bill introduced and presented not as a measure of welfare but as a measure of finance. Not once did the government spokesperson mention that this bill finally puts an end to universality.
The purpose behind universal family allowance, which is being dispensed with, ended in this legislation, is to recognize the important task of raising children by all families, regardless of their income levels. Yet this bill is saying to Canadian families that a large number of them are not to receive anything in recognition of their participation in raising children, in raising Canada's future. It is opposed by all groups working on behalf of children and families. It is the end of universality as is being produced here in this legislation.
Even if some families are going to be a little better off, and as I said some will be $1.25 a day better off, this government over the last few years has taken billions of dollars out of social programs and billions of dollars out of transfers to the provinces.
In my own province of Saskatchewan $518 million will not come to the province this year that otherwise would have. That $518 million is about the same size as the provincial deficit, in a small province with limited ability to raise tax dollars, with a small population, indeed a shrinking population. Here the government is taking $518 million out of the province of Saskatchewan and it is putting a few dollars back at the rate of $1.25 to lower income families.
It cannot be said to be progress when you take millions out and you put a few cents back. Many families in Saskatchewan and Saskatoon-Clark's Crossing do not have adequate resources to feed their families because they cannot get jobs. The unemployment rate is around 12 per cent. The government is telling those families they are not going to be better off; they are going to be worse off. They are not going to receive any assistance. They are going to be worse off in the end.
Let us look at one single instance. The government says that it is putting $400 million more into these child benefits, as I said, prorated to $1.25 a day per family, but it is taking $620 million out of social housing across the country. On that one item $220 million is lost to those Canadians at the low end of the economic earning capacity, who need some help to afford housing, to provide adequate housing for their families, housing which is too expensive for them in the private sector. Even on that one issue lower income Canadians are losing about $200 million; the difference between the cut to social housing and the extra money in the child benefits.
The federal unloading on to the provinces is costing Canadian families enormously and the federal government is just throwing a few cents their way in response to that. The federal support has been reduced considerably. Canadian families know that.
In spite of the attack on the resources of the provinces, there are some opportunities which have been taken. The three provinces with NDP governments, British Columbia, Ontario and Saskatchewan, have all been able, in spite of the desperate financial situations they

Government Orders
have been in, to increase social assistance rates. They recognized the plight of Canadians living so far below the poverty line.
Let us look a little at what is wrong with what the government has done. It says that its new child benefits package is simpler, fairer and more generous, whereas in fact, as I have tried to show, it is none of these things.
First of all, it is not markedly simpler. There is a reduction of categories of sets of benefits from five to four, but this new system remains so complicated that the government, not individual families, will have to calculate the benefits.
As I have said, it is not fair. It does not provide to Canadian families with low incomes the ability to feed their children. It does not enable them to get out of the welfare trap, as the government tries to pretend it does.
What the government has done in this case is distinguish between the deserving poor and the undeserving poor. Whether or not children are poor is not a question of whether or not they are deserving. They do not become undeserving because they are members of a particular family or deserving because they are members of another family. Yet this government has decided that it would add $500 a year to working poor families, but not to families without the opportunity to work. With the costs of child care being anything upwards from $6,000 a year, the extra $500 clearly will not be of much assistance to those families.
It is said that the program is more generous. As I and the government's own officials have said, the poorest of Canada's poor children will be no better off at all under this program. Of course with deindexation, everyone who receives the benefits will become worse and worse off over time.
What did the government do to let Canadians know about its new child benefits package, even though it did not have much to work with? As I have said, the poorest will remain poor. It spent $500,000 on an advertising campaign to promote the new child benefits program. It spent $500,000, money which surely would have been better spent on feeding those hungry children.
What should we do instead? It is not enough just to criticize the woefully inadequate programs that the
government puts forward. It is necessary to suggest some alternatives for the government, not that it will listen, it has not listened to any of the critics. So far it has not listened to those people who know how lower income Canadians have difficulty in getting by from day to day.
We must set the reduction of poverty as a realizable goal. We must fight for it. We must make sure that we work toward reducing poverty in Canada. Yet over the last 10 years, in the time that this government has been in office, there has been no decrease in the number of children living in poverty. That number is about the same as it was 10 years ago.
We have to get Canada working again. We have to place employment at the top of our list of priorities. We cannot continue to fight inflation by creating unemployment, as this government has done. We cannot continue to fight rising interest rates by creating unemployment. It is an immoral, unacceptable way of organizing our resources.
We have to put full employment strategies first. We have to make sure that we treat the creation of jobs as our number one priority. We have to also support that policy with adequate training programs, not for just 6 per cent of those people who are on unemployment insurance but for all Canadians so that they can become better trained and better able to cope with the needs of a modem economy.
We need a fair taxation system so that those who are richer and the corporations that make profits will pay their fair share of taxes. Canadians do not mind paying their fair share of taxes, but they do not like being treated unfairly. They do not like to see the Royal Bank or the big banks paying no taxation essentially, while their taxes are increased on a yearly basis. Every time the finance minister produces a budget, his hand goes into the pockets of ordinary Canadians. Yet tax loopholes for the rich and corporations continue to flourish. That is an unacceptable approach.
We have to try to stop poverty. This government has tended to allow poverty to take place and, indeed, through its economic policies to encourage poverty and then attempt to respond with band-aid solutions. We would be best off to invest in our children, to invest in our future and ensure that Canadian children do not
June 1, 1992

grow up in poverty and that they grow up with the basic necessities of life.
To summarize, we need full employment policies. To suggest as some on the other side would that this is impossible is only to close their eyes to countries across this world that have put employment first, to successful economies with low unemployment rates and low child poverty rates, too. For example, we could look to Norway as a country which could show us how to ensure our children do not live in poverty but are provided with the basic necessities of life. In Norway, the child poverty rate is 5 per cent. In Canada, we are dealing with one in six Canadian children living in poverty. There are examples to follow. There are other countries we can look to.
As I said, we need fair taxes so that we can find the revenue to provide for those who, for whatever reason, are unable to work. We need affordable, accessible, high quality, non-profit child care so that parents can go out to work. That is something the government has reneged upon only recently.
Canada's record among the industrialized countries in the world with regard to child poverty is better only than that of the United States. Only the United States is worse than we are. All other countries are better and it is time we looked to them for examples.
I will end on one rhetorical question. Do we not have the resources in this country to ensure that no children go to bed hungry? Surely we can organize our resources appropriately so that those children who will be our future have the resources they need, the food they need, the education they need. Can we not organize our resources so that can be done? Surely we can, if we have the political will.

Madam Speaker, I listened very carefully to what was said by the previous speaker, and I would like to say that he made a very good speech in which he analysed the essential components of the family allowance policy. However, before that I also listened to the speech by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Finance, and I was very disappointed that it was so simple, I would almost say simplistic, for a major debate on the universality of programs like family allowances.
I was surprised at his petty dollars and cents approach and his explanation that it was actually better for all concerned, when we know this entails an enormous loss in terms of vested rights many Canadian families have had for years.
Madam Speaker, I am sure that like me, you remember the universal family allowances program, a program that has benefited all Canadian families. Irrespective of income or marital status, this program was universal. Today, we are witnessing the end of the universality of family allowances, and you know as well as I do, Madam Speaker, that a program for the poor always ends up being a poor program. Every time we decide to change the rules of the game to give one group an advantage over another group, the losers are the people on the borderline.
The problem with this government proposal is that our tax system could be fairer. Members loiow as well as I do that those who earn more would normally pay more income tax and those who earn less would pay less. Consequently, things could be evened out at that level. However, they now want to decide arbitrarily, and this is supposed to be a measure by the Department of Finance, but basically, this marks the end of a truly universal program in this country. The government has done it again. It did exactly the same when it set a ceiling on old age security pensions, and today, in a matter of hours, another national institution, a program which the Prime Minister himself said was a sacred trust, will disappear.
I saw the Prime Minister with my own eyes at Patro Roc-Amadour in Quebec City, when he was on television, promising his mother I remember, it was the 1988 election campaign that he would never touch the universality of old age pensions. I know because some of my

Government Orders
colleagues were in that room and remember it very well. Again, he lied to us, and now family allowances are disappearing for all practical purposes.
I know that hon. members opposite would like to say that family policy is strictly an accounting operation. I know that we should have had a much more substantial debate before coming to that conclusion. Basically the whole Canadian social safety net which they are advertising, instead of spending money to have young girls sing "O Canada", that money could be much better spent to help children have school lunches or things like that. Obviously the government's priorities are misplaced and more and more we are forced to realize that this government's family policy is going nowhere.
After he solemnly promised a national child care program-I heard it too-the Minister of National Health and Welfare says it is out of the question. They went back on their word once more. Imagine, the major social programs about which Canada boasts around the world are being eroded one after another.
That is why when we see people traipsing around the world, trying to pretend to be virtuous, we should look at reality. We do not have to go very far. I am sure that in any primary school, you could find children who have not been fed because they are poor. The $1.04 a day under this program will certainly not be enough to feed them. It is not even enough for a bus ticket. We know very well that this program which the government would have us believe is an incentive and generous perpetuates child poverty. Even worse, it is just the beginning.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The hon. member knows very well that this period is for short comments and questions or comments on the previous speech and questions for the member who just spoke.
The hon. member has already been talking for over five minutes. Perhaps he could conclude with a question for his colleague.
The hon. member for Shefford.

Madam Speaker, you guessed that I was coming to the questions, because that is just what I was about to do.
I wanted to ask my colleague if he does not find it indecent for a government to come with a bill like this
without dealing with the fundamental issue in Canada and Quebec for taxpayers. I think removing the universality of social programs through the back door, using a Department of Finance that has a petty accountant's mentality-does the hon. member not find that dishonest? Is it not rather crooked of the government to have done it to old people and now do it to families? Is it not going back on its promises one by one? I think that the hon. member would have something to say about that.

Madam Speaker, I would like to thank the member for his question. Clearly we share the same view regarding universality that the majority of Canadians share, and it is that we see the raising of children as a responsibility of all Canadian families. That should be recognized by the government on behalf of all Canadians.
After all, it will be those children who will pay the pensions for you, me, and everybody else and provide for our health care as they move into the work force and pay their taxes. If we do not respect them, if we do not honour them, if we do not recognize them then they are likely to be less prepared to provide us with pensions, health care and so on. Even in terms of self-interest it is a big mistake to attack universality.
Those programs of universal application of family benefits, the family allowance, some of that money goes into families which are a little wealthier. If we had a taxation system which responded well and in a progressive way, if we were taxed back much of that money, we would be able to recognize those families' contributions to the raising of children as something which is beneficial to Canada and we would be able to recover some of those moneys in terms of taxation.
By undermining universality and by increasingly turning our taxation system into a regressive system, we are undermining those roles on two accounts.
It is worth pointing out that all critics of social programs will tell you that once you remove universality you begin the process of removing the program altogether. That is what we are seeing here, the continual erosion over time, first of universality and now of social programs directed toward the poor.
June 1, 1992

It is also worth pointing out that by not encouraging those children of lower income families, by not ensuring that they attend school and can stay awake because they are well fed, we encourage a huge cost on our society. One study has suggested that the school drop-outs in one year, from 1989, will cost Canada $4 billion. There are suggestions that school drop-outs over a decade will cost $30 billion. Those are huge costs to society because we are not paying enough attention to our children.
Were it not for the government's refusal to look from the heart at these problems, to be compassionate and caring about the pain and suffering that its economic and social policies are causing Canada's low income children, perhaps it could look at it from an economic point of view, from a financial point of view, and see the huge costs that are being loaded on this country.
Madam Speaker, whether it be from economic or social reasons, it surely is necessary for this government to change its policies.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I consider it a great pleasure to support this legislation, Bill C-80, with regard to strengthening Canada's income assistance measures for children.
I have listened very carefully to some of my colleagues in the House and I just want to say at the very beginning that what we are talking about today is certainly a major change, I grant that; but it also is $2.1 billion in new money. This is new money that is going to the assistance of children. We are streamlining this system so it can be passed through to the families far more effectively. It is a lot fairer, it is a lot simpler and it is a lot more generous.
These really sweeping changes did not come about suddenly, they have been under review for years and years, both in the standing committees of this House and the other place down the hall. It was most interesting, if you chronologically go back, to note that the Prime Minister attended the United Nations meeting on the rights of the child and we ratified the Canadian position on children's rights on December 11, 1991.
Also, the standing committee on health and welfare had a report. I also would like to thank my colleague from Calgary North who through a great many meetings
Government Orders
with various members of Parliament has gone through each and every area with regard to the benefits in assisting families, and we feel we have come up with a very good system.
When the Minister of Finance on February 25 brought in his annual budget for the present fiscal year, he tabled a white paper on the child benefit.
I noticed that some of my colleagues opposite were mentioning that there was no communication and no discussion with regard to the child benefit package with the agencies, various provinces and the Canada Assistance Plan people.
The department has sent out thousands of copies of the white paper to interested people and the Minister of National Health and Welfare and the Minister of Finance have been talking to the provincial agencies right across Canada to review exactly what is in the benefit and looking for input.
I mentioned the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and I mentioned the budget that was brought down in February. I would also like to say that the Minister of National Health and Welfare brought down Brighter Futures a few weeks ago, which is a plan that deals specifically with children at risk.
We are all very worried about youngsters in poverty. We must be very careful to be fiscally responsible as well as socially responsible. In taking a strong look and in talking to people right across Canada we know that we must assist those who are high risk. That is indeed what the Minister of National Health and Welfare brought down.
He took the money, $500 million, and is utilizing it to target youngsters who are really at risk through prevention, through education, and through promotion. He is promoting through the various agencies, hospitals, clinics, and our aboriginal colleagues how to take care of oneself when one is pregnant, to cure the low birth weight of some new youngsters, and introduce more education for health protection gear for children's safety. We have also joined partnerships right across Canada. That is another element.
I am really glad to speak today because this tremendous change in our legislation represents the final one.

Government Orders
There were many areas of the old act that were causing us a great deal of concern. I would like to say that I believe that there is absolutely no doubt that the new child tax benefit put forward in the bill today is a significant advancement over the current system. In light of today's complex society, and we heard from the gentleman across the way that it is a complex society, the bill proposes enriched benefits which will be streamlined and be very responsive. It will better target the ones who need our help.
I did mention the two parliamentary committees and the member for Calgary North. The proposed benefit is going to be a single monthly payment for children under 18. It will generally be made to the mother. This new benefit is going to be based on family income reported in the most recent tax year. These single monthly payments will neither be taxed nor recovered at tax time. Those are two important changes so that families are going to keep in full what they receive.
There are two major components of the proposed tax benefit. The first is the basic monthly benefit that replaces family allowances, the dependent child credit and the refundable child tax credit. It includes extra benefits for children under the age of seven and also for children in large families.
The second major change is a new federally earned income supplement. This is veiy important. It is a federally earned income supplement that will increase the basic benefit by up to $500 per year for low-income working families with children. While we will maintain and increase our benefits for those people living on welfare we are going to give some added incentive to low-income working families. Today there needs to be an incentive for people to get out and work. It is most important.
The annual benefit is going to depend on family earnings, the number of children, and the age of the youngsters. It is going to prove to be a lot simpler and fairer.
The child tax credit will be made up of a base amount of $1,020 per year for each child with a $75 supplement for the third and subsequent children. The base amount is increased by a further $213 per year for each child under the age of seven if child care expenses are not claimed at the time.
The basic child tax benefit amount is going to be paid in full to all families with incomes up to $25,921. The benefit will gradually be reduced for those with incomes above that particular amount.
In addition, the $500 per year income supplement for the low-income working families is to be phased-in for families earning above $3,750. This supplement is going to reach its full and maximum benefit if family earnings are $10,000 or more. It will only be reduced when the family income exceeds $20,921.
It is very important and we can debate these things when it goes to the legislative committee. Let us look at what it means to the average Canadian family.
Under the new system a single mother with an income of $30,000 and two children over the age of seven would receive $153 a month in 1991. She will be better off by about $300 per year under our new system.
A mother with three children over the age of seven and a total family income of $22,000 in 1991 will be eligible for the basic amount of $261.25 plus an earned income supplement of $32.68 per month. Basically, this means she is going to receive $293.93 a month beginning January 1,1993 and she is going to be better off by about $400 per year.
This new system is intrinsically a lot fairer. It is not based on individual income; it is based on family income. This is what Canadians have been telling us for years. It is targeted at those who need it the most. We have taken a look at the total system and we will target those people with lower and middle incomes. The assistance will be focused on the low and the middle income.
The child tax benefit will gradually be reduced with incomes above designated thresholds. Obviously the more money earned above a threshold, the benefit will slowly be reduced.
The entire benefit is going to be paid monthly, making it easier for families to budget. It will not be taxed and it will not be recouped at the year end. The benefit will be paid to the parent who needs it the most and it is a fundamental design of redoing the tax system.
I am not suggesting for one minute we are backing away from universality. What we have done here is become very fiscally responsible while being socially responsible. It is a new system which is more generous. It is $2.1 billion more generous than the current system over a five-year period.
June 1, 1992	COMMONS
The government has committed these new funds to assist families and it is going to assist over 2.4 million families. They are all going to have their benefits increased.
Some 2.4 million families are going to receive more benefits. Over two-thirds of those particular families have incomes under $50,000. No family below $50,000 is going to lose benefits.
There is a whole bunch that won't get anything.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
The bill before us today underscores our commitment. The member for Kingston and the Islands does not seem to realize that some people at $50,000 a year with youngsters do need benefits, absolutely.
This is why out of the 2.4 million people whom we are helping with increased benefits nobody under $50,000 a year is going to lose. That is very important. The economic and fiscal statement starting in 1984 accompanying the agenda for economic renewal have been our key policies throughout the past five, six, seven, eight years.
The child and the elderly benefit consultations paper profiled a number of options for child benefits and it encouraged public participation. That is what we have taken into account, the public consideration.
In 1985, as I said, we had the parliamentary standing committee on health and welfare. We had another one that reported in December just past with regard to the social conditions and the poverty under which some youngsters in Canada and indeed some lower income families are living. We have taken into consideration all the recommendations that have been put forth.
We have to invest in our future, as my colleague from Saskatchewan mentioned. Children are our future. Day after day we see areas throughout Canada that need attention. I support many of my colleagues with regard to the need to attack poverty. It is very important.
The end result of an extensive review over the past five or six years and consolidation of the particular programs that we are putting into Bill C-80 today are of utmost importance to all Canadians. Once people see the system they will greatly appreciate it.

Government Orders
I thank the staff of both departments in charge of the implementation of the new program. We are working with finance as well as with health and welfare. It has been a monumental task that will be implemented only if this House along with the other House approves. It is going to mean the switching of some 3.7 million files in health and welfare for the new program.
The member mentioned that copies of the white paper had not been sent out. It was my colleague from Winnipeg who spoke earlier. I really want to assure him that information has gone out all across Canada dealing with this specific policy. In no way would we be implementing something that we did not have agreement on.
Poverty is a major issue. I know everyone in the House has heard the hon. minister address that specific issue. None of us should rest while there is one youngster living in poverty. We have also addressed the fiscal constraints we are living under. We have hard choices to make: to spend more money we could raise taxes, increase the deficit or cut other programs.
The Minister of Finance, as he so carefully worded it in his budget in February, made it extremely clear that it was through cuts in certain areas, in program expenditures, that he was able to recoup the $2.1 billion to put into this new child benefit package.
We have not increased the deficit for this. We have not increased taxes. Indeed what we have increased are the benefits to youngsters and we can all commend the Minister of Finance.
Some of us are well aware of the problems under the old system. There were delays in receiving the refundable child tax credit. Often families could not gain from any child tax benefit for a year. It was veiy inconvenient. Each benefit was delivered in an entirely different way, which meant that there were eligibility criteria for every particular program. This made it very difficult.
For the eight years I have been here-I am sure, Madam Speaker, you are well aware of this too-we have been told that there are certain higher income people who do not perhaps need the family allowance as much as the lower income people. We had inadequate targeting under the old system.

June 1, 1992
Private Members' Business
I look forward to working with my colleagues on all sides of the House at the legislative committee. I am sure there are some areas of the bill we can improve, but I am in support of Bill C-80.
